LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 

capacity  development 

Socialist Republic of Viet Nam 
 
Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sectors (subsectors): Agriculture and natural resources (irrigation, 
drainage,  and  flood  protection);  education  (tertiary  and  higher 
education) 
Themes  (subthemes):  Economic  growth  (widening  access  to 
markets and economic opportunities), governance (economic and 
(institutional 
financial  governance); 
development) 
Location impact: Rural (high), urban (low), national (medium) 
Partnership: Agence Française de Développement (AFD) 
 
Category: B 
Initial environmental examinations were undertaken. 
 
The  project  is  designed  to  address  two  binding  constraints  that 
contribute to the core sector problem of poor quality and delivery 
of  water-related  services.  These  constraints  are  insufficient 
human  resource  capacity  and  inadequate  public  infrastructure. 
The  project  will  address  these  constraints  by  funding  education 
facilities to train engineers in water-related fields that are needed 
to  meet  the  heightened  demands  of  a  rapidly  growing  economy. 
The  project  will  also  address  the  requirements  of  dilapidated 
irrigation and drainage infrastructure with funding to upgrade and 
modernize the management of irrigation canal systems. It will help 
the  government  increase  the  number  of  qualified  agriculture-
related  water  management  engineers,  improve  the  governance 
and  management  of  irrigation  systems,  increase  agricultural 
production,  and  improve  the  productivity  of  project  areas  to 
increase poor farmers' incomes and reduce poverty. 
 
Irrigated agriculture is by far the largest user of water in Viet Nam. 
Paddy rice is the dominant crop, accounting for more than 80% of 
the  total  irrigated  area.  However,  the  area  of  paddy  land  has 
decreased  in  recent  years  with  diversification  to  aquaculture  and 
other  crops  and  economic  growth  sectors  other  than  agriculture. 
This  has  increased  the  demands  placed  on  water  resources  and 
caused  reallocation.  To  meet  growing  demand  for  rice  and 
maintain food security, it is essential to increase crop productivity 
and the efficiency of production inputs, especially water.  
 

 

 ii 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Impact and Outcome 

 
Project Investment Plan 

 
Financing Plan 

 
Viet Nam has about 100 large and medium-scale hydraulic works 
for irrigation and drainage. One of the oldest and largest is the 50-
year-old  Bac  Hung  Hai  (BHH)  irrigation  and  drainage  system  in 
the heart of the Red–Thai Binh River basin, which covers part or 
all of the provinces of Bach Ninh, Hung Yen, and Hai Duong east 
and  southeast  of  Ha  Noi  (see  map).  Given  this  system’s 
importance to the economy, social welfare, and food security, and 
its  advanced  state  of  disrepair,  its  rehabilitation  is  one  of  the 
government’s top investment priorities. 
 
Water Resources University (WRU) is a public institution that was 
established  in  1959  under  the  auspices  of  the  Ministry  of 
Agriculture  and  Rural  Development  (MARD).  The  existing  WRU 
campus  is  in  the  center  of  Ha  Noi  City.  The  site  for  the  new 
campus  is  on  agricultural  land  in  Chuong  My  District,  15 
kilometers west of the existing campus. WRU is the only university 
in Viet Nam with a full program of subjects necessary to educate 
water engineers. Operating for more than 50 years, it has trained 
more than 18,000 engineers in water-related fields, many of which 
pertain  to  irrigation  and  drainage.  The  existing  campus  was 
originally built for 3,000 students, and the university cannot meet 
the growing demand for qualified water specialists and engineers. 
WRU intends to increase its enrollment in stages from the current 
9,500 students to 13,400 by 2012 and 17,500 by 2020. However, 
it will not be able to achieve its targets unless its physical facilities 
are improved to expand its training capacity. 

The impact of the project is to contribute to increased agricultural 
productivity  in  the  BHH  area.  The  outcome  of  the  project  is  to 
strengthen  the  quality  of  water-related  services  provided  by 
MARD.  
 
The  total  project  cost  is  estimated  at  $179.0  million,  including 
taxes and duties of $16.9 million and contingencies.   
 
The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  provide  a  loan  of  $100 
million equivalent in special drawing rights from its Special Funds 
resources 
including 
infrastructure  for  WRU  and  BHH  and  capacity  development  and 
project management costs. AFD will provide a loan of €20 million 
(equivalent to $28.0 million at the prevailing exchange rate) on a 
parallel collaborative cofinancing basis to finance 15.6% of project 
costs. AFD will administer its loan and finance BHH infrastructure 
subprojects  in  the  provinces  of  Hung  Yen,  Hai  Duong,  and  Bac 
Ninh,  including  investment  priorities  identified  by  stakeholders  in 
the Gia Binh pilot area of Bac Ninh Province. The government will 

finance  55.8%  of  project  costs,

Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development 
 
MARD  has  delegated  executing  agency  responsibility  to  the 
central  project  management  unit  (CPMU)  in  its  Central  Project 
Office.  The CPMU  will  (i)  manage  and  coordinate  the  project;  (ii) 
liaise  with  implementing  agencies  to  improve  WRU  facilities  and 
BHH  irrigation  management  systems;  (iii)  implement  the  project 
performance  and  monitoring  system;  (iv)  procure  goods,  civil 
works  and  consulting  services;  (v)  coordinate  with  implementing 
agencies  the  procurement  of  goods  and  services;  (vi)  prepare 
forecasts  of  contract  awards  and  disbursements  and  arrange 
project  account  audits;  and  (vii)  prepare  project  reports  including 
the  project  completion  report.  Five  project  management  units 
(PMUs) will be established. Each province will establish only one 
PMU to maximize the effective use of resources and ensure good 
coordination  among  project  activities.  Project  implementation 
consultants will help the PMUs to (i) construct facilities for the new 
campus of WRU; (ii) improve irrigation management systems; (iii) 
construct  new  irrigation  infrastructure;  (iv)  rehabilitate  existing 
irrigation 
infrastructure;  (v)  procure  goods,  civil  works  and 
consulting  services;  (vi)  operationalize  the  project  performance 
and  monitoring  system;  and  (vii)  implement  resettlement  plans, 
environmental management plans, and the gender action plan.  

 

 iv 
Procurement 

 
Consulting Services 

 

All  procurement  under  the  ADB  loan  will  be  undertaken  in 
accordance  with  ADB  Procurement  Guidelines 
(2007,  as 
amended from time to time). Procurement under the AFD loan will 
follow  AFD  procurement  guidelines.  International  competitive 
bidding (ICB) procedures will be applied for the construction of the 
WRU  facilities  and  major  BHH  construction  packages.  For  the 
BHH infrastructure component, separate packages will be bid out 
for the construction or rehabilitation of pump stations in the three 
provinces,  each  of  which  will  be  managed  either  by  the  Central 
Project  Office  or 
the  provincial  PMU,  depending  on  size, 
complexity,  and  regional  importance.  The  Co  Ngua  pump  station 
will be procured through a turnkey contract to be managed by the 
Central  Project  Office,  under  which  the  detailed  design,  civil 
works,  and  supply  and  installation  of  equipment  will  be  provided 
through  a  single  contract.  Turnkey  and  civil  works  contracts 
estimated to cost more than $2 million equivalent will be procured 
through ICB. Civil works contracts estimated to cost $2 million or 
less will be procured through national competitive bidding. Goods 
will  be  procured  through  ICB  where  the  cost  is  more  than  $1 
million,  national  competitive  bidding  where  the  cost  is  from 
$100,000 to $1 million per package, and shopping where the cost 
is less than $100,000. MARD may purchase items below $10,000 
directly from the supplier.  
 
All consultants to be financed under the ADB loan will be recruited 
in  accordance  with  ADB  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants 
(2007, as amended from time to time). The project will require 236 
person-months  of  national  consultancy  and  56  person-months  of 
international. An international firm of consultants will be recruited 
to  strengthen  national  capacity  and  provide  assistance  with 
project  implementation.  National  consultants  will  be  recruited  for 
preparing detailed designs and resettlement plans, as well as for 
independent  external  monitoring  of 
implementation  of 
resettlement  plans  and  environment  management  plans.  Various 
selection  methods  will  be  applied  in  recruiting  consultant  firms, 
including  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  with  a  standard 
quality:cost ratio of 80:20, consultants' qualification selection, and 
fixed  budget  selection.  Individual  consultants  will  be  engaged 
following  ADB  procedures

for

be  recruited,  rather  than  individuals.  All  consulting  packages  will

A  total  of  560,000  people  in  the  BHH  area  will  benefit  from 
increased  household  incomes  from  improved  irrigation.  This  will 
allow households to diversify and intensify agricultural production 
and  increase  their  incomes.  A  total  of  1.9  million  people  in  the 
BHH area will benefit from improved drainage and reduced risk of 
flooding.  The  indirect  beneficiaries  of  the  BHH  component  of  the 
project are 2.8 million women and men living in the four provinces 
covered by the system, which includes all or parts of the provinces 
of  Hung  Yen,  Hai  Duong,  and  Bac  Ninh,  as  well  as  Ha  Noi  City. 
improved  agricultural 
The 
productivity through upgraded hydraulic structures and equipment 
for controlling the timing and allocation of irrigation and improving 
agricultural and  non-agricultural  drainage  conditions,  (ii)  irrigation 
water savings that can be allocated to other community livelihood 
needs,  (iii)  the  promotion  of  institutional  arrangements  that 
enhance water user participation in irrigation and drainage system 
management,  and  (iv)  greater  protection  for  people  and  their 
assets from flooding throughout the system. 
 
A  total  of  13,400  future  students  and  800  faculty  members  will 
benefit from improved quality of education and improved learning 
and  accommodation  facilities  at  the  new  WRU  campus.  The 
benefits will include (i) improved teaching and learning facilities for 
faculty members and students; (ii) dormitory space for 30% of the 
student population, with 50% of this space reserved for women to 
the  new  campus,  and  (iii) 
encourage 
accommodation  for  ethnic  minorities  and  other  disadvantaged 
groups. In addition, the influx of students and teachers will create 
new  employment  and  income-generating  opportunities  for  the 
residents  of  Chuong  My  District,  where  the  new  campus  will  be 
located.  A  total  of  37,777  people  live  in  villages  surrounding  the 
campus and will be preferred for campus jobs. Chuong My District 
has  a  population  of  290,449  that  will  indirectly  benefit  from  the 
income-generating  opportunities  the  university  community  will 
create in the area. This population will also benefit from increased 
education opportunities for youths. 
 
 
Delays  in  implementation  may  be  caused  by  slowness  in 
recruiting  consultants  and  appointing  appropriate  central  and 
provincial  project  management  staff,  the  resistance  of  vested 
interests  to  changes  in  the  organizational  structure  of  service 
providers,  cumbersome  administrative  processes  related 
to 
contract  awards,  and 
insensitive  handling  of  resettlement. 
Resettling and compensating people affected by construction are 
critical  because  the  commencement  of  disbursements  for  civil 
works contracts is conditional upon their prior completion. Project 
consultants  will  help  provincial  authorities  complete 
land 
acquisition and resettlement on schedule. MARD has experience 
in and good understanding of government and ADB requirements 
for resettlement.

Concerns  exist  about  steadily  declining  water  levels  in  the  Red 
River,  which  are  likely  caused  by  the  operation  of  the  upstream 
reservoirs,  changes  in  water  use,  and  morphological  changes  in 
the  Red  River  Delta.    An  assessment  undertaken  during  project 
preparation  indicated  that  at  some  locations  the  riverbed  has 
eroded by up to 2 meters. The subsistence is most likely the result 
of morphological changes from the large quantities of sand mined 
and  sediment  retention  in  upstream  reservoirs,  disturbing  the 
dynamic equilibrium of the river system. To address this situation, 
upstream  reservoirs  will  need  to  release  more  water  to  achieve 
the  design  water  level  at  the  BHH  Xuan  Quan  intake  during  the 
dry  season  in  January  and  February,  when  agricultural  land  is 
prepared for planting. 
 

  

 

  

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Socialist  Republic  of  Viet  Nam  for  the  Strengthening  Water  Management  and  Irrigation 
Systems Rehabilitation Project. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

1. 

The Macroeconomic Context 

2. 
Viet Nam's economy has expanded rapidly in the past 2 decades. Real gross domestic 
product (GDP) grew at the average annual rate of 7.4% in 1988–2007. Rapid economic growth 
and  increasingly  efficient  social  protection  brought  a  substantial  reduction  in  poverty.  The 
proportion of people living on less than $1 per day based on purchasing power parity dropped 
from 50.8% of the population in 1990 to 4.0% in 2007, and the proportion of those living on less 
than $2 per day based on purchasing power parity fell from 87.0% to 32.9%.2  
 
3. 
However,  Viet  Nam  has  experienced  serious  macroeconomic  difficulties  since  2008.  It 
suffered high inflation in the first half of 2008 partly because of a sharp rise in world commodity 
prices  and  was  hurt  by  the  global  economic  crisis  in  the  second  half.  Largely  because  of  the 
crisis,  exports,  international  tourist  arrivals,  and  inflows  of  remittances  and  foreign  direct 
investment  declined  in  2009.  GDP  growth  slowed  to  6.2%  in  2008  and  5.3%  in  2009.  The 
government  responded  to  the  crisis  swiftly  and  forcefully.  It  loosened  monetary  policy 
significantly  in  late  2008  and  early  2009  and  adopted  a  number  of  fiscal  stimulus  measures, 
including additional social assistance to poor households, in the first half of 2009. The slowdown 
in growth was therefore relatively modest, and the poverty rate remained on a downward path. 
The proportion of people living below the official poverty line fell from 14.8% in 2007 to 13.4% in 
2008 and 12.3% in 2009. 
 
4. 
Three-quarters of the population and more than 90% of the poor live in rural areas, and 
70% of the income of rural inhabitants comes from agriculture. Agriculture (including fishery and 
forestry) accounted for half of employment but only 20.7% of GDP in 2009. Labor productivity in 
agriculture  will  need  to  grow  if  the  real  incomes  of  agricultural  workers  are  to  keep  pace  with 
national averages. Many agricultural workers will seek higher-paid employment in industry and 
the  services.  That  many  of  these  jobs  will  be  in  urban  areas  suggests  an  accelerating  rural–
urban transition.  
 
5. 
The  Red  River  Delta  is  one  of  the  key  economic  hubs  of  the  country,  but  the  region 
faces  serious  economic  challenges.  Unemployment  in  this  area  is  higher  than  in  most  other 
regions  of  the  country.  Given  the  high  population  density  of  some  1,250  people  per  square 
kilometer  and  small  land  holdings  (most  smaller  than  0.2  hectares),  people  will  depend 
increasingly  on  services  and  industry  for  continued  economic  growth  and  thereby  increase 
demands on water resources to meet multiple purposes. The sector analysis is in Appendix 2.

 2 

 

2. 

Water Resources and Irrigation 

6. 
The  government  places  high  priority  on  irrigation  modernization,  dam  safety,  and 
improved water resources management. The government’s 5-year Socioeconomic Development 
Plan  for  2006–2010  aims  to  promote  sustainable  development  and  improved  quality  and 
efficiency  of  growth.  One  of  the  major  objectives  is  to  accelerate  agricultural  and  rural 
industrialization  and  modernization  geared  toward  forming  large-scale  agricultural  commodity 
production relevant to market demand and the ecological conditions of individual regions. The 
modernization  of  irrigation  and  drainage  systems  will  result  in  more  reliable,  efficient,  and 
equitable water services, which are indispensable for agricultural modernization.  
 
In  its  National  Water  Resources  Strategy,3  the  government  has  defined  the  main 
7. 
objectives  for  the  water  sector  in the  15  years  to  2020  as  the  protection,  efficient exploitation, 
and  sustainable  development  of  water  resources  on  the  basis  of  integrated  and  unified  water 
resources  management.  The  continuous  development  and  improvement  of  institutions, 
operations, and colleges working in the field of water resources are priorities of the strategy and 
necessary  for  enhancing  capacity  for  developing  human  resources.  With  rapid  economic 
growth, demand for water engineers in Viet Nam is growing by 4% per annum, which exceeds 
the capacity of the existing universities to educate sufficient numbers of qualified graduates to 
effectively  manage  water  resources,  particularly  those  required  in  the  irrigation  and  drainage 
subsector, given its importance in the water sector.4 
 
8. 
Water Resources University (WRU) is a public institution established in 1959 under the 
auspices of the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (MARD). During its 50 years of 
operation, WRU has trained more than 18,000 engineers in water-related fields, of whom more 
than  80%  continued  to  work  in  these  professions,  many  pertaining  to  irrigation  and  drainage. 
Over  the  years  the  situation  at  WRU  stagnated,  with  the  training  program,  teaching 
methodology,  and  reference  materials  lacking  needed  innovations.  The  curriculum  was 
outdated,  the  subjects  taught  were  not  fully  diversified,  and  the  training  methods  focused  on 
theory  with  little  practical  skills  development.  However,  with  recent  government  support  and 
concerted  development  partner  efforts,  the  situation  has  improved.5  In  2007,  WRU  achieved 
formal accreditation. A self evaluation was submitted to the Ministry of Education and Training, 
and  an  external  evaluation  committee  visited  WRU  in  2009.  Thereafter  WRU  received 
accreditation, based on a good overall performance. 
 
WRU’s  development  strategy6  is  intended  to  guide  its  becoming  one  of  the  10  leading 
9. 
universities in Viet Nam and fulfil its aim of preparing highly qualified human resources to meet 
the  development  requirements  of  the  water  sector.  The  early  stages  of  the  plan  introduce 
appropriate  mechanisms  to  improve  staff  quality,  develop  educational  curricula,  improve  and 
extend  educational  programs,  improve  teaching  methodologies,  attract  financial  contributions, 
develop and upgrade infrastructure, and mobilize capital and financial resources. WRU intends 
to  broaden  its  international  and  regional  cooperation  with  academic  institutions  and  research 
centers,  which  will  bring  access  to  international  advanced  university  education  standards  and 
the capacity to develop scientific research collaboration in areas of common interest.

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

1. 

Irrigation Performance 

10. 
The major binding constraints in the water sector relate to outmoded management and 
lack  of  capacity.  MARD  and  other  national  agencies  involved  in  managing  and  using  water 
follow  an  engineering,  sectoral  approach  to  water  resource  development  and  have  yet  to  fully 
assimilate  integrated  water  resources  management  into  their  planning  strategies  and  work 
practices.  Provincial  agencies  have  considerable  authority  to  make  key  decisions  on  water 
infrastructure development and management, subject to conformity with national sector policies 
and  strategies,  but  their  capacity  to  target  poverty  in  water  projects  and  coordinate  various 
cross-sectoral  aspects  of  water  resources  management  is  limited.  Irrigation  management 
companies  (IMCs)  are  state-owned  public  utilities  responsible  for  the  operations  and 
maintenance (O&M) of large irrigation systems but display little service orientation or capacity to 
manage  irrigation  in  a  sustainable  manner.  Maintenance  is  frequently  neglected  in  favor  of 
government-financed periodic rehabilitation. Water end users have yet to be fully empowered to 
make water management decisions affecting their livelihoods.  
 
11. 
However, Viet Nam has a number of strengths on which to build an improved irrigation 
and  drainage  subsector.  In  2006,  regulations  were  issued  enabling  provinces  to  modify  the 
structure  and  roles  of  their  departments  of  agriculture  and  rural  development  (DARDs)  and  to 
make  concomitant  changes  in  the  central  irrigation  and  drainage  management  companies 
(IDMCs)  and  the  provincial  IMCs.  These  reforms  were  to  encourage  water  management 
companies  to  develop  business  plans  based  on  needs  rather  than  government  fiat  and  to  set 
realistic  user  fees  subject  to  guaranteed  service  delivery.  The  formal  separation  of  service 
providers (IDMCs and IMCs) from regulators and resources managers (MARD and DARDs) is a 
hallmark  of  a  maturing  water  economy.  Important  relationships,  such as  those  between  IMCs, 
irrigation management enterprises (IMEs),7 and communes, are governed by formal constraints 
rather than informal agreements, which provide sound bases for future improvements. 
 
12. 
In  2004,  MARD  launched,  with  financial  assistance  from  the  World  Bank,  the  Vietnam 
Water  Resources  Assistance  Project,8  a  national  program  to  rehabilitate  six  of  the  largest 
irrigation  systems  in  the  country  and  establish  a  service-oriented  approach  in  which  provincial 
agencies  and  water  users  are  empowered  to  jointly  manage  irrigation  systems.  In  this  way, 
MARD  sought  to  raise  the  efficiency  of  water  delivery  and  realize  the  full  potential  of  its 
investments.  In  the  same  year,  MARD  approved  and  issued  guidelines9  for  establishing, 
strengthening,  and  developing  water  users  associations  (WUAs),  which  facilitated  the 
implementation  of several  participatory  irrigation  management  (PIM)  projects  with  international 
funding. MARD concurrently established a program to accelerate PIM implementation with the 
aim  of  transferring  responsibility  for  O&M  to  farmers.  This  is  being  piloted  under  the  Second 
Red River Basin Sector Project.10 
 
13. 
Until  recently  the  system  of  irrigation  service  fees  (ISFs)  differed  by  region,  land  use, 
and  the  water  supply  system  (gravity,  pumping,  or  mixed).  However,  in  November  2008  ISF

O&M,  and  protection  of  the  hydraulic  works  and  canals  located  in  their  districts  to  meet  irrigation  and  drainage 
requirements for agricultural production and demand for domestic water supplies.

stipulations  were  amended  with  a  number  of  exemptions,  which  effectively  abolished  the  ISF 
with effect from 1 January 2009.11 Instead of paying IMCs for water and services, farmers now 
enter  into  contracts  with  their  water  users  groups  (WUGs)  or  cooperatives,  which  enter  into 
contracts  with  IMCs  for  providing  communal  irrigation  services.  Upon  certified  delivery  of  the 
contracted  irrigation  services,  a  government  subsidy  is  paid  to  the  IMC  for  fulfilling  the  order 
defined  in  the  contracts.  Central  IDMCs  are  now  subsidized  by  the  state,  and  provincial  IMCs 
are subsidized by provinces to the extent of forgone ISFs. The Ministry of Finance is the lead 
agency for the subsidy system and coordinates its implementation with MARD. Close monitoring 
and evaluation of the measures the government has proposed to address the implications of the 
ISF  waiver  policy  are  required  to  ascertain  the  ultimate  impact  of  the  ISF  waiver  policy.  The 
institutional setting is described more thoroughly in Supplementary Appendix A. 
 

Asian Development Bank's Strategy for Water Sector Operations 

2. 
The strategic focus of the country strategy and program for Viet Nam, 2007–201012 is to 
14. 
support  business-led,  pro-poor,  and  sustainable  economic  growth.  It  takes  a  results-oriented 
approach  that  is  directly  linked  to  supporting  the  targeted  outcomes  of  the  government's 
Socioeconomic  Development  Plan.  Weak  public  administration  and  poor  governance  of  state-
owned enterprises are key constraints on the mobilization and efficiency of public investments 
and hinder the effective delivery of  public services.  The project is consistent with this strategy 
and  will  contribute  to  improved  governance  and  sustained  economic  growth  in  Viet  Nam.  It  is 
also  consistent  with  the  mission  and  vision  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  pursued 
under  its  Strategy  2020,13  which  focuses  on  inclusive  growth  and  environmentally  sustainable 
development while remaining dedicated to poverty reduction. 
 

3. 

Development Coordination 

15. 
ADB  and  four  other  international  development  partners  (IDPs)  are  particularly  active  in 
water  resources  and  the  irrigation  and  drainage  subsector  in  Viet  Nam:  Agence  Française  de 
Developpement (AFD), Japan International Cooperation Agency, Royal Netherlands Embassy, 
and World Bank. Development coordination for water resources and the irrigation and drainage 
subsector is described in Appendix 3. 
 
ADB leads and coordinates institutional development initiatives for legislative and policy 
16. 
development  and  strengthening  capacity  for  sustainable  water  resources  management.  It 
administers  IDPs'  contributions  for  technical  assistance  (TA)  including  TA  for  Institutional 
Development of the Second Red River Basin Sector Project;14 and TA for Water Sector Review 
and  National  Targeted  Program  for  Water  Resources  Development.15  ADB  has  also  engaged 
IDPs  to  support  the  government  with  water  source  protection  through  improved  irrigation  and 
drainage infrastructure development by providing financial assistance.16

5 

Analyses  of  ADB  projects  in  the  irrigation  subsector  have  consistently  shown  that  a 
17. 
broad systems approach is needed to identify constraints and the means of overcoming them. 
Such  an  approach  draws  development  planners,  implementers,  operators,  and  users  into  a 
partnership  for  improved  project  design  and  system  management.  In  disaster-prone  areas, 
improved performance also depends on putting into place effective risk reduction. Achieving full 
potential requires practical and holistic interventions to (i) build the capacity of key stakeholder 
agencies at various levels, including introducing community-based, demand-driven approaches 
such as PIM; (ii) eliminate physical impediments to efficient system operation; and (iii) provide 
support for project management. 
 
18. 
Pertinent lessons from these initiatives include the need for (i) strengthening capacity to 
further  develop  the  water  resources  sector  to  ensure  the  success  of  future  investments;  (ii) 
capacity building by combining formal training and learning-by-doing in the presence of effective 
support  from  the  center;  (iii)  project  planning  based  on  a  river  basin  development  approach, 
undertaken  in  an  overall  system  context  and  addressing  key  constraints  in  an  integrated 
manner;  (iv)  a  holistic  approach  to  irrigation  system  upgrading  and  development  with  the 
definition  of  lower  level  requirements  at  the  outset  and  a  program  to  address  the  most  critical 
constraints;  and  (v)  a  more  participatory  approach  to  project  design  through  extensive 
consultation  with  primary  stakeholders,  especially  for  identifying  investment  priorities  in 
secondary  and  tertiary  drainage  and  irrigation  systems,  including  the  alignment  and  level  of 
canals  and  drains,  location  of  major  structures,  and  placement  of  spoil  from  excavations. 
Factors commonly  associated  with  successful capacity  development  projects include  thorough 
project  preparation,  close  coordination  among  funding  agencies,  and  administration  by  the 
resident mission. 
 

4. 

Project Rationale 

19. 
Viet Nam’s population of more than 86 million is predominantly rural, with 63 million, or 
73%,  dependent  on  agriculture  for  livelihoods  and  basic  needs.  Viet  Nam  has  been  one  of 
Asia’s  fastest-growing  economies  over  the  last  20  years.  The  contribution  from  agriculture, 
forestry,  and  aquaculture  to  the  GDP  is  still  about  20%,  and  the  sector  leads  all  others  in  job 
creation. Viet Nam is a net food exporter and currently the world’s second-largest rice exporter 
after Thailand. However, with the population growing at 1.4% per year and improving standards 
of  living,  rice  consumption  is  increasing  at  an  even  higher  rate.  The  exported  rice  surplus  will 
soon be required for domestic consumption if there is no increase in production. If such trends 
continue, Viet Nam will eventually need to import some staple foods. 
 
20. 
The surge in food prices in 2008 caused the world food situation to take a dramatic turn, 
affecting  poor  and  vulnerable  people  who  spend  a  substantial  part  of  their  income  on  food. 
Although Viet Nam remains a net exporter of grains, it has been facing the challenge of sharp 
increases  in  food  and  fuel  prices,  which  threaten  macroeconomic  stability  and  overall  growth. 
The  most  adversely  affected  are  poor  households  in  the  cities,  smallholders,  the  landless, 
marginal farmers who are net food buyers, and nonfood producers in rural areas, who spend a 
large  share of  their  incomes  on  food.  The  government  has  recognized  the  importance  of  food 
security  and  focused  resources  on  maintaining  a  strong  position  in  terms  of  national  grain 
reserves. Investment in irrigation has been considered a key measure. 
 
21. 
Irrigated  agriculture  is  by  far  the  largest  user  of  water  in  Viet  Nam,  using  more  than 
65.5 billion  cubic  meters  (m3)  per year,  or  80%  of  total  water  use.  Paddy  rice  is  the  dominant 

                                                                                                                                                          
(Loan  2025-VIE,  for  $90.0  million,  approved  on  9  January  2004);  and  Central  Region  Water  Resources  Project. 
Manila (Loan 2223-VIE, for $74.3 million, approved on 19 December 2005).  

 

 6 

 

crop, accounting for more than 80% of the total irrigated area. However, the area of paddy land 
has decreased in recent years with diversification to aquaculture and other crops and economic 
growth in sectors other than agriculture. This has increased demands on water resources and 
caused reallocation. To meet growing demand for rice and maintain food security, it is essential 
to improve crop productivity and the efficient use of production inputs, especially water.  
 
22. 
Currently the country's irrigation supply is inefficient; its infrastructure is old, dilapidated, 
and  reliant  on  state  budgets  and  official  development  assistance  to  keep  systems  operating. 
The government's ISF waiver policy has exacerbated the situation, placing full responsibility for 
financing  the  O&M  of  main  irrigation  system  infrastructure  on  the  government's  budget.17  To 
maintain food security in the long term, the government needs to pursue reforms to create an 
innovative and progressive irrigation and drainage subsector. 
 
23. 
Viet Nam has about 100 large and medium-scale hydraulic works systems for irrigation 
and  drainage.  One  of  the  oldest  and  largest  is  the  50-year-old  Bac  Hung  Hai  (BHH)  irrigation 
and drainage system in the heart of the Red–Thai Binh River Basin, which covers part or all of 
the  provinces  of  Bach  Ninh,  Hung  Yen,  and  Hai  Duong  (see  map).  The  physical  area  of  the 
system is 192,045 hectares (ha), of which 146,756 ha, or 76%, is used for agriculture, mainly to 
grow paddy rice. Rice production was 1.1 million tons in 2008. The population of the provinces 
and  districts  encompassed  by  the  command  area  is  2.8  million,  of  whom  2.2 million  work  in 
agriculture.  Given  the  importance  of  the  BHH  irrigation  and  drainage  system  to  the  economy, 
social welfare, and food security, and its advanced state of disrepair, its rehabilitation is one of 
the government’s top investment priorities. 
 
The focus of project investments in the BHH system will be to improve the efficiency of 
24. 
existing water resources in the system that are needed to increase agricultural productivity and 
maintain  production  in  the  area.  This  will  be  accomplished  partly  through  institutional 
development  with  the  application  of  participatory  approaches  for  modernizing  BHH  systems 
management. Participatory approaches will include measures to increase the representation of 
women  in  WUGs.  Irrigation  efficiency  will  also  be  addressed  by  rehabilitating  critical  irrigation 
and  drainage  infrastructure,  which  will  also  adapt  the  BHH  system  to  the  changing  land-use 
situation in the area.  
 
25. 
The main campus of WRU is in the center of Ha Noi, housing nine faculties. A second 
campus  is  located  in  Ho  Chi  Minh  City,  and  there  are  research  centers  in  other  parts  of  the 
country. The site for the new campus is on agricultural land in Chuong My District, 15 kilometers 
west of the existing Ha Noi campus. WRU is the only university in Viet Nam with a full program 
of subjects necessary to educate water engineers.18 The existing campus was originally built for 
3,000  students.  Currently  9,500  students,  23%  of  whom  are  women,  are  enrolled  at  WRU, 
which cannot meet growing demand for qualified water specialists and engineers. WRU’s two-
phase development strategy for 2006–2020 includes training 17,500 water engineers by 2020, 
with an enrollment of 13,400 students by the end of phase 1 in 2012.19 However, it will not be 
able  to  achieve  its  targets  unless  its  physical  facilities  and  capacity  are  improved  through

III. 

THE PROPOSED PROJECT 

A. 

Impact and Outcome 

26. 
The impact of the project is to contribute to increased agricultural productivity in the BHH 
area.  The  outcome  is  to  strengthen  the  quality  of  MARD’s  water-related  services.  The  project 
will improve technical supervision and the management competency of stakeholders involved in 
delivering irrigation and drainage services in the BHH irrigation and drainage system, including 
local  beneficiaries.  It  will  achieve  higher  operational  efficiency  in  irrigation  and  drainage 
systems. The outcome will be influenced by policy dialogue with the government during project 
implementation. This will include addressing urgent needs for capacity development to ensure 
effective  project  implementation  and  institutional  reforms  needed  to  streamline  processes  and 
promote integrated water resources management. Dialogue will address O&M issues, including 
the implications of the government's ISF waiver policy. 
 
B. 

Outputs 

27. 
The  project  is  designed  to  address  two  binding  constraints  that  contribute  to  the  core 
sector  problems  of  poor  quality  and  delivery  of  water-related  services:  (i)  insufficient  human 
resource  capacity  and  (ii)  dilapidated  public  infrastructure.  The  project  will  address  these 
constraints  by  funding  education  facilities  to  train  engineers  in  water-related  fields  that  are 
needed to meet heightened demand in a rapidly growing economy. The project will address the 
requirements  of  dilapidated  irrigation  and  drainage  infrastructure  with  funding  to  upgrade  and 
modernize the management of the BHH irrigation system. The project will help the government 
increase the number of qualified agriculture-related water management engineers, improve the 
governance  and  management  of  irrigation  systems,  increase  agricultural  production,  and 
improve the productivity of project areas to increase poor farmers' incomes.  
 

1. 

New Educational Facilities for Water Resources University 

28. 
The  project  will  finance  the  construction  of  a  major  portion  of  the  first  phase  of  a  new 
campus for WRU in Chuong My District of Ha Noi City, comprising a well-balanced, functional 
mix  of  educational  facilities  sufficient  for  13,400  students  and  dormitories  for  30%  of  them  by 
2016. New high-standard facilities for training water resources specialists will be constructed for 
seven  faculties  including  (i)  classrooms,  laboratories,  lecture  halls,  faculty  libraries,  teachers’ 
offices,  and  administration  offices;  (ii)  dormitories  to  accommodate  up  to  4,022  students,  with 
50%  of  spaces  for  women;  (iii)  3,246  square  meters  of  laboratory  buildings;  and  (iv)  outside 
parking  for  125  cars.  With  the  government's  support  for  the  implementation  of  the  WRU 
strategy, further international and regional cooperation with academic institutions and research 
centers,  and  continued  donor  support  for  institutional  development,  infrastructure  investments 
under the project will enable a significant increase in the number of well-qualified bachelor and 
master  of  science  graduates  from  WRU  in  agriculture-related  water  management.  The 
development of the new WRU campus is fully described in Supplementary Appendix C. 
 

2. 

Construction and Rehabilitation of BHH Irrigation and Drainage 
Infrastructure 

The  project  will  finance  the  construction  of  eight  new  pumping  stations  and  the 
29. 
rehabilitation of two existing pumping stations for irrigation, drainage, and dual purposes in the 
BHH  system.  These  investments  will  increase  irrigation  capacity  by  13.2  m3/second,  serving 
11,200  ha  in  the  Gia  Thuan  area  of  Bac  Ninh  Province,  and  increase  drainage  and  internal 

 

 8 

 

irrigation capacity by 135.2 m3/second, meeting increased demand by 2016 and serving 49,000 
ha. These investments will increase paddy productivity per hectare by 12%, from an average of 
6.0  tons/ha  in  2009  to  6.7  tons/ha  by  2020,  and  raise  cropping  intensity  from  2.09  crops  per 
year in 2009 to 2.24 by 2020. BHH subproject descriptions are in Supplementary Appendix D. 
 

3. 

Strengthening Capacity of BHH Service Providers 

30. 
The project will strengthen the capacity of water management organizations throughout 
the BHH system with capacity development and the establishment of a first-phase supervisory 
control and data acquisition (SCADA) system, launched on a pilot basis in the Gia Binh area of 
Bac  Ninh  Province.  An  AFD-funded  grant  associated  with  this  activity  will  facilitate  a 
participatory  approach  to  identifying  investment  priorities  for  strengthening  local  water 
management and upgrading secondary and tertiary canal system infrastructure in the pilot area. 
Management capacity in the pilot area will be strengthened through community-based, demand-
driven  approaches  including  PIM.  These  institutional  development  initiatives  will  facilitate  the 
strengthening of IMCs and IMEs through the provision of modern management techniques and 
equipment, as well as training to operate and maintain the tools and technologies introduced. 
 

4. 

Project Management 

31. 
The project will support the establishment of a project management structure along with 
strengthening  capacity  for  efficient  and  effective  implementation.  A  baseline  survey  will  be 
undertaken  within  6  months  of  project  effectiveness.  With  the  help  of  project  implementation 
consultants,  the  project  performance  and  monitoring  system  (PPMS)  will  be  fully  operational 
within 1 year of project effectiveness. 
 
C. 

Special Features 

1. 

Quality of Services for Irrigation Canal Operations 

32. 
An approach being followed for designing improved irrigation systems management and 
quality  of  services  under  the  project  is  Mapping  Systems  and  Services  for  Canal  Operation 
Techniques  (MASSCOTE),20  which  is  a  methodology  for  modernizing  canal  irrigation  systems 
and  improving  the  performance  of  conjunctive  water  supplies  for  multiple  stakeholders.  The 
Food  and  Agriculture  Organization  of  the  United  Nations  has  introduced  this  approach  in  the 
People's  Republic  of  China  and  Thailand,  where  it  has  been  effective  and  popular.  During 
project preparation, a 2-week MASSCOTE workshop was conducted with the participation of 24 
engineers and irrigation professionals, including 9 managers of the BHH irrigation and drainage 
system.21 The workshop included a survey of the BHH system and assessment of the quality of 
water-related services delivery to farmers based on indicators of rate, duration, and frequency of 
irrigation water supply at various levels throughout the system.  
 

2. 

Pilot for Improved Water Management  

33.

implementation of a pilot in the Gia Binh area of Bac Ninh Province.22 The pilot will identify the 
priorities  needed  for  improved  delivery  of  irrigation  and  drainage  services,  ensuring  that  the 
benefits  of  investment  in  irrigation  infrastructure  reach  the  intended  farmer  beneficiaries,  both

male  and  female.  Following  the  MASSCOTE  approach,  a  step-by-step  analysis  leading  to  a 
draft consolidated vision of the future of the BHH irrigation and drainage system and a plan for 
progressively  modernizing  its  irrigation  management  and  canal  operations  will  be  formulated 
and  implemented.23  A  portion  of  the  AFD  loan  will  be  applied  to  rehabilitating  irrigation  and 
drainage infrastructure in the Gia Binh area that will be identified through the process. The AFD 
grant for the Gia Binh pilot is described in Supplementary Appendix E. 
 

3. 

Improved Monitoring and Modernization of Water Control 

A systematic study monitoring water levels and flows for modernizing water control was 
34. 
undertaken  during  project  preparation.  Initially,  gates  in  the  control  structures,  or  regulators, 
along  the  main  canals  and  at  primary  off-takes  will  be  motorized.  Further  automation  through 
the  use  of  programmable  local  controllers  will  be  applied,  and  three  large  regulators  and  off-
takes will be motorized. Other off-takes will be equipped with conventional gates associated with 
a flow-measuring device. The aim is to improve the operation of the main systems by installing a 
SCADA  system,  providing  remote  supervision  and  monitoring  capability.  It  is  intended  that 
SCADA will ultimately be used for the remote monitoring of all main irrigation water intakes, both  
gravity and pumped; all drainage pump stations and sluices; and main regulators and off-takes.  
 

4. 

Institutional Change 

A regulatory framework is being formulated in Viet Nam that enables IMC autonomy and 
35. 
the  transfer  of  rights  to  own,  use,  and  manage  irrigation  facilities  to  IMCs  and  WUGs. 
Government Decree 95/2005 provides the basis under which IMCs can be converted into one-
member  limited  companies,  which  allows  much  more  management  flexibility,  including 
delegation  of  responsibility  relating  to  staffing,  procurement,  and  finances.  Government  at  all 
levels  supports  improving  the  irrigation  and  drainage  situation  in  the  BHH  system  by 
modernizing its management and making it more decentralized and participatory. This presents 
an opportunity for the project to catalyze important and far-reaching institutional changes at the 
central, provincial, and lower levels, particularly affecting the structure and operations of IMCs 
and  their  relationships  with  client  water  users.  It  will  help  bring  to  agriculture  the  benefits  of 
state-owned enterprise reform that has been effective in more industrialized sectors. The project 
will  help  to  lay  the  groundwork  for  privatizing  water  management  organizations  in  the  BHH 
system. This, coupled with strong support for gender-sensitive PIM, will place the project at the 
forefront  of  the  government's  reform  agenda  in  irrigated  agriculture.  Transferring  publicly  held 
assets to legally constituted WUGs and WUAs will empower water users, both women and men, 
to take part in decisions that affect their well-being and strengthen system sustainability.

Financing Plan 

37. 
ADB  will  provide  a  loan  of  $100  million  equivalent  in  special  drawing  rights  from  its 
Special Funds resources to finance 55.8% of project costs, including infrastructure for WRU and 
BHH,  capacity  development,  and  project  management.  AFD  will  provide  a  loan  of  €20  million 
(equivalent to $28 million at the prevailing exchange rate) to finance 15.6% of the project costs 
on  a  parallel  collaborative  cofinancing  basis.  AFD  will  administer  its  loan  and  finance  BHH 
infrastructure  subprojects  in  Hung  Yen,  Hai  Duong,  and  Bac  Ninh  provinces,  including 
investment priorities identified by stakeholders in the Gia Binh pilot area of Bac Ninh Province.24 
The  government  will  contribute  $51  million  to  finance  taxes  and  duties,  the  costs  of  initial 
detailed design and other consulting services, land acquisition and resettlement costs, and part 
of  operational  costs,  accounting  for  28.5%  of  project  costs.  The  ADB  loan  portion  will  have  a 
maturity of 32 years, a grace period of 8 years, and an interest rate of 1% per annum during the 
grace period and 1.5% thereafter. Subject to confirmation, the AFD loan will have a maturity of 
20 years, a grace period of 7 years, and an interest rate of 2%, matching the Europe interbank 
offered rate. The government will bear the foreign exchange risk. Interest charges on the loans 
will be capitalized.

Implementation Arrangements 

1. 

Project Management  

38.  MARD  has  delegated  the  role  of  executing  agency  to  the  central  project  management 
unit  (CPMU)  in  its  Central  Project  Office  (CPO),  which  is  led  by  a  project  director  with  fully 
delegated  responsibility  for  decision  making.  The  CPMU  comprises  full-time,  qualified,  and 
experienced  staff  of  the  CPO,  some  of  whom  have  specialized  technical  skills.  Implementing 
agencies include WRU, BHH IDMC, and DARDs in the BHH provinces of Bac Ninh, Hung Yen, 
and  Hai  Duong.  The  CPMU  will  (i)  manage  and  coordinate  the  project;  (ii)  liaise  with 
implementing agencies to improve WRU facilities and BHH irrigation management systems; (iii) 
implement the PPMS; (iv) procure goods, civil works and consulting services; (v) coordinate with 
implementing  agencies  the  procurement  of  goods  and  services;  (vi)  prepare  forecasts  of 
contract  awards  and  disbursements  and  arrange  project  account  audits;  and  (vii)  prepare 
project  reports  including  the  project  completion  report.  Project  implementation  consultants  will 
assist the CPMU with these tasks. Project organization and flow of funds is in Appendix 5. 
 
39. 
Five project management units (PMUs), headed by project managers with qualifications 
acceptable to ADB will be established under the direct administration of WRU, BHH IDMC, and 
the  provincial  DARDs.  The  PMUs  will  comprise  full-time  qualified  and  experienced  staff.  Each 
province  will  establish  only  one  PMU  to  maximize  the  effective  use  of  resources  and  ensure 
good coordination of project activities. Consultants will help the PMUs (i) construct facilities for 
the  new  campus  of  WRU;  (ii)  improve  irrigation  management  systems;  (iii)  construct  new 
irrigation  and  drainage

PPMS; and (vii) implement resettlement plans, environmental management plans (EMPs), and 
the gender action plan.25 Capacity building and strengthening organizations will be among the 
main foci of the consultants’ tasks.

The  CPO  has  good  capacity  and  extensive  experience  in  managing  and  implementing

5. 

Anticorruption Policy 

47. 
ADB's Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government.  Specific  concerns  from  experience  on  other  projects  include  the 
government's preference to split civil works into many small contract packages and award them 
to local contractors. This causes problems for supervision and quality assurance and increases 
scope  for  corruption.  Consistent  with  its  commitment  to  good  governance,  accountability,  and 
transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly or through its agents, any alleged 
corrupt,  fraudulent,  collusive,  or  coercive  practices  relating  to  the  project.  To  support  these 
efforts,  relevant  provisions  of  ADB's  Anticorruption  Policy  are  included  in  the  loan  agreement 
and  the  bidding  documents  for  the  project.  In  particular,  the  project  will  incorporate  certain 
anticorruption  measures:  (i)  All  contracts  financed  by  ADB  in  connection  with  the  project  shall 
include provisions specifying the right of ADB to audit and examine the records and accounts of 
MARD and all contractors, suppliers, consultants, and other service providers as they relate to 
the  project.  (ii)  The  project  will  have  a  website  that  discloses  its  implementation  progress,  bid 
notifications, and their results, as well as provides a grievance mechanism against any corrupt 
practice. (iii) The project will reduce the number of contracts by packaging similar contracts and 
introducing turnkey contracts.

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

A. 

Beneficiaries 

53. 
A total of 560,000 people in the BHH area will benefit from increased household incomes 
from  improved  irrigation.  This  will  allow  households  to  diversify  and  intensify  agricultural 
production  and  increase  their  incomes  through  a  12%  improvement  in  paddy  productivity  per 

 

  

15 

hectare and an increase of cropping intensity from 2.09 crops per year in 2009 to 2.24 in 2020. 
A total of 1.9 million people in the BHH area  will benefit from improved drainage that reduces 
the  risks  of  flooding.  The  indirect  beneficiaries  of  the  BHH  component  are  2.8  million  women 
and  men  living  in  the  four  provinces  covered  by  the  system,  which  includes  all  or parts  of  the 
provinces of Hung Yen, Hai Duong, and Bac Ninh, as well as Ha Noi City. Most people in the 
BHH  area  are  employed  in  agriculture,  ranging  from  60%  to  98%  across  project  districts.  The 
2.8 million women and men will benefit indirectly from improvements in the system management 
and  overall  performance.  These  benefits  will  include  (i)  improved  agricultural  productivity 
through upgraded hydraulic structures and equipment for controlling the timing and allocation of 
irrigation  water  and  improving  agricultural  and  non-agricultural  drainage  conditions,  (ii)  saved 
irrigation water that can be allocated to other community livelihood needs, (iii) the promotion of 
institutional  arrangements  that  enhance  water  user  participation  in  irrigation  and  drainage 
system  management,  and  (iv)  greater  protection  of  people  and  their  assets  from  flooding 
throughout the system. 
 
54. 
A  total  of  13,400  future  students  and  800  faculty  members  will  benefit  from  improved 
quality  of  education  and  improved  learning  and  accommodation  facilities.  The  benefits  of  the 
WRU  component  will  include  (i)  improved  teaching  and  learning  facilities  for  faculty  members 
and students, at least 26% of whom will be women based on present trends; (ii) dormitory space 
for  30%  of  the  student  population,  with  50%  of  this  space  reserved  for  women  to  encourage 
them  to  study  at  the  new  campus;  and  (iii)  accommodation  for  ethnic  minority  students  and 
other  disadvantaged  groups,  which  can  be  expanded  as  the  student  population  grows  at  the 
new  campus.  In  addition,  the  influx  of  students  and  teachers  will  create  new  employment  and 
income-generating opportunities for the residents of Chuong My District, where the new campus 
will  be  located.  A  total  of  37,777  people  live  in  villages  surrounding  the  campus  and  will  be 
preferred  for  campus  jobs.  Chuong  My  District  has  a  population  of  290,449  who  will  indirectly 
benefit  from  the  income-generating  opportunities  the  university  community  will  create  in  the 
area. Residents will also benefit from increased education opportunities for youths.  
 
B. 

Social Aspects 

55. 
A social analysis has been carried out to assess the likely impact of the project and to 
develop safeguards for land acquisition and resettlement. The project will contribute to poverty 
reduction through increased economic growth in the Red River Delta. The 2007 poverty rate in 
the target provinces ranged from 8.4% in Ha Noi City to 13.4% in Hai Duong, compared with the 
national  rate  of  14.8%.  While  this  is  not  a  targeted  poverty  intervention,  the  project  area  has 
highly  productive  agricultural  land  and  a  growing  industrial  base  that  is  important  to  assuring 
domestic  food  supply  and  driving  national  economic  growth.  The  summary  poverty  reduction 
and  social  strategy  is  in  Appendix  9,  and  the  full  poverty  and  social  assessment  is  in 
Supplementary Appendix I. The gender action plan is in Supplementary Appendix J. 
 
56. 
The  project  will  develop  capacity  to  improve  the  responsiveness  of  BHH  system 
management  to  the  needs  of  water  users  and  increase  the  participation  of  water  users  in 
planning  and  decision-making.  The  interventions  planned  under  the  BHH  component  include 
measures  to  enhance  the  participation  of  women  in  WUAs  and  overall  system  management. 
Project activities will increase the representation of poor households in WUAs and enhance the 
responsiveness  of  system  management  to  poverty  reduction  that  can  be  addressed  through 
irrigation  services,  including  greater  efficiency  through  increased  capacity  of  irrigation  and 
drainage infrastructure. The civil works to be completed for the project will create employment in 
project  areas,  and  women  and  the  poor  will  be  preferred  for  related  jobs.  The  poor  will  also 
benefit from the services that arise on the perimeter of the new WRU campus. 
 

 

 16 

 

57.  Most agricultural workers in the BHH irrigation and drainage system are women. Women 
will  benefit  from  improvements  in  irrigation  water  supply.  They  are  most  affected  by  problems 
such as drought as their workload increases with the need to manually water crops. The social 
analysis  shows  that  women  are  less  involved  than  men  in  community  decision-making,  and 
interventions to improve BHH system management will address the role of women in WUAs.  
 
58. 
The  new  WRU  campus  will  have  positive  social  impacts  as  it  will  provide  better 
conditions  for  students  and  teachers  for  study  and  research.  The  new  campus  will  provide 
improved  accommodation  and  sanitation,  which  will  benefit  poor  students,  especially  females. 
Indirect benefits include the new jobs the campus site will create for local residents both during 
and after construction. 
 
The project will require land acquisition from approximately 800 households at the WRU 
59. 
campus  site  and  300  households  in  the  BHH  area.  The  project  minimizes  the  number  of 
households  that  will  lose  their  principal  dwelling,  with  fewer  than  100  requiring  relocation.  A 
resettlement  framework  outlines  how  the  project  will  mitigate  the  negative  impacts  faced  by 
people  who  lose  agricultural  land  or  have  to  relocate.  The  resettlement  framework  is  in 
Supplementary Appendix K. Resettlement plans for both the WRU and BHH components have 
been prepared to document resettlement impacts and costs. The resettlement plan for the WRU 
component  includes  an  income-restoration  program  that  will  include  providing  household 
members  who  lose  agricultural  land  with  jobs  generated  by  the  new  WRU  campus.  WRU  will 
favor hiring local residents during and after construction. The summary resettlement issues are 
in  Appendix  10.  The  resettlement  plans  for  the  WRU  and  BHH  components  are  in 
Supplementary Appendix L. There are no indigenous people or ethnic minority groups present 
in project locations and so no implications for ADB's Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998). 
 
C. 

Environmental Impacts 

The realization of the new WRU campus will have a strong positive impact on the higher 
60. 
education  system  in  Viet  Nam.  Similarly,  the  selected  subprojects  for  the  BHH  system  will 
improve  the  irrigation  and  drainage  situation  and  are  expected  to  increase  agricultural 
production.  Screening  of  both  components  shows  that  the  new  WRU  campus  and  the  BHH 
subprojects will produce only slight and moderate adverse environmental impacts and are both 
classified category B, in accordance with ADB regulations. The adverse environmental impacts 
will occur mainly during construction and can be mitigated by proper design, sound engineering, 
and specific mitigations measures framed as contractual obligations of the contractor, as well as 
by  correct  O&M  procedures  after  project  completion.  Positive  impact  can  be  expected  in  the 
BHH  system  with  improved  water  conveyance,  which  will  improve  water  quality,  and  the 
removal of stagnant water through improved pumping capacity, which will limit the duration and 
depth  of  flooding.  Consequently,  the  initial  environmental  examinations  (IEEs)  carried  out  for 
both  components  are  sufficient,  in  accordance  with  ADB  environmental  guidelines.  The  IEEs 
include EMPs, which will be updated with detailed designs to ensure that all potentially adverse 
impacts  are  adequately  mitigated  and  monitored.  Institutional  arrangements  for  implementing 
and monitoring the EMPs are provided in the IEEs. Public consultations have been conducted 
on  environmental  issues  pertaining  to  the  WRU  campus  and  each  subproject  of  the  BHH 
system. The summary IEE is in Appendix 11. The IEEs are in Supplementary Appendix M. 
 
D. 

Economic Impacts 

The  project  is  expected  to  yield  major  benefits,  including  (i)  incremental  benefits  from 
61. 
higher  crop  yields  and  productivity  through  upgraded  hydraulic  structures  and  equipment  for 
controlling  the  timing  and  allocation  of  irrigation  water  and  improving  agricultural  and  non-

 

  

17 

agricultural  drainage  conditions;  (ii)  saved  irrigation  water  that  can  be  allocated  to  other 
community livelihood needs; (iii) greater protection of people and their assets from flooding; (iv) 
improved  knowledge  through  capacity  building  and  practical  training  in  more  efficient 
institutional  arrangements  that  enhance  water  user  participation  in  irrigation  and  drainage 
system  management;  (v)  increased  numbers  of  bachelor  and  master  of  science  graduates 
through  newly  constructed  educational  facilities;  and  (vi)  significant  contributions  to  improved 
water management and reduced rural poverty in the project provinces. This will help ease social 
pressures  to  migrate  to  urban  centers  like  Ha  Noi  and  Hai  Phong  and  contribute  to  balanced 
development in Viet Nam in the medium term. The only source of benefits that can be readily 
quantified for benefit–cost analysis is the increased yield of crops and aquaculture attributable 
to improved irrigation water availability in the BHH system.  
 
Besides  quantifiable  benefits,  there  are  a  variety  of  benefits  that  cannot  be  readily 
62. 
quantified.  First,  investment  and  better  maintenance  of  the  BHH  system  will  improve  flood 
protection through improvements in the tidal water regulation and 10 new or renovated irrigation 
and drainage pumping stations. Based on the estimated cost of flood damage in 2001–2008 in 
BHH  areas  of  the  project  provinces,  the  project  is  estimated  to  save  $3.2  million  per  annum. 
However,  savings  from  avoided  damage  were  not  included  into  the  benefit–cost  analysis  as 
annual frequencies and magnitude are uncertain.  
 
Second,  the  benefits  of  improved  irrigation  normally  include  both  direct  benefits,  i.e., 
63. 
those accruing to the farming community, and indirect benefits, i.e., those accruing to the wider 
local  economy.  The  indirect  benefits  of  improved  irrigation  include  backward  linkage  effects 
because  of  additional  inputs  (labor  and  material  inputs)  used  in  irrigated  agriculture  due  to 
improved  crop  productivity,  made  possible  by  better  access  to  irrigation.  Indirect  effects  of 
irrigation arise from income and employment effects in the agro-industry and non-farm sectors 
of the rural economy. The indirect benefits of irrigation spread to the region as a whole, such as 
increase  in  direct  agriculture  production  as  well  as  allied  agriculture  sector  activities,  and 
increase  in  other  rural  agro-services  and  marketing  in  the  economy.  Therefore,  the  indirect 
benefit of irrigation plays a larger role in poverty alleviation and maintaining food security than 
does the direct benefit in terms of increased crop productivity. Although It is not easy to quantify 
these  benefits  precisely,  in  developing  economies  such  as  Viet  Nam  where  agriculture 
production  is  better  organized  than  elsewhere  in  the  developing  world,  the  irrigation 
multiplication factors have been observed to be in the range of 1.5–2.0 times direct benefits. 
 
64. 
Third,  capacity  building  is  a  key  element  for  development  and  the  implementation  of 
strategies and policies in water resources management in general and in relation to agriculture 
sector development. The project will assist the government in capacity building at the national, 
provincial, and district levels. Though difficult to quantify, benefits derived from capacity building 
for  MARD,  WRU,  DARDs,  and  entities  operating  the  BHH  system  will  ensure  improved  water 
resource management in the country in the medium and long term. 
 
65. 
The benefit–cost analysis of the project was based on incremental benefits from higher 
crop yield and productivity. The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was calculated for the 
project  to  determine  its  economic  viability  and  serve  as  the  monitoring  benchmark  for  project 
implementation. The base-case EIRR was estimated at 22.6%, economic net present value at 
$70.3 million, and benefit–cost ratio at 1.66. 
 
These indicators suggest that the project is economically viable, with a base-case EIRR 
66.  
well  above  the  12%  economic  opportunity  cost  of  capital  for  the  quantified  benefits.  The 
summary  economic  analysis  is  in  Appendix  12,  and  detailed  assumptions,  financial  and 

 

 18 

 

economic  production  budgets,  derived  economic  prices,  project  capital  and  recurrent  costs 
profiles, and benefit–cost and sensitivity analyses are in Supplementary Appendix N.  
 
67. 
Sensitivity tests were undertaken to assess the robustness of the analyses and examine 
the  consequences  of  changes  in  variables,  including  capital  costs,  O&M  of  civil  infrastructure, 
system  dredging  costs,  benefits,  pumping  costs,  and  the  earlier  pump  replacement  schedule. 
The tests were undertaken with the following variables: (i) increase of 10% in the capital cost, 
(ii)  increase  of  10%  in  civil  infrastructure  O&M  costs,  (iii)  increase  of  10%  in  system  dredging 
costs,  (iv)  combined  ii  and  iii,  (v)  decrease  of  10%  in  benefits,  (vi)  combined  iv  and  v,  (vii) 
decrease  of  20%  in  benefits,  (viii)  increase  of  10%  in  pumping  costs,  (ix)  1-year  delay  in 
benefits, and (x) pumps replaced after 15 years instead of 20 years.  
 
The  sensitivity  tests  indicate  that  the  BHH  subprojects  are  highly  sensitive  to  the 
68. 
following cases: (i) a reduction of 10% in benefits and an increase of 10% in capital, O&M, and 
system dredging costs, which cause the base-case EIRR to fall to 18.2%;  (ii) a 1-year delay in 
realization of benefits, which reduces the base-case EIRR from 22.6% to 18.5%; and (iii) a 20% 
decrease in benefits, which reduces the base-case EIRR to 18.5%. 
 
E. 

Risks 

69. 
The results of economic and financial sensitivity analysis strongly indicate that delays in 
project implementation and the lack of cost-control and good governance are among the major 
risks  of  the  project.  It  is  strongly  recommended  that  (i)  capacity  development  for  project 
management and implementation be frontloaded, (ii) counterpart funding be readily available to 
minimize  implementation  delays,  and  (iii)  cost-control  measures  and  transparent  financial 
management  and  governance  be  established  for  the  project  before  implementation  to  ensure 
cost  efficiency.  Financial  management  assessment  of  project  operating  entities  indicated  that 
systems are in place to handle project finance. However, it is recommended that staff be trained 
and  familiarized  with  ADB  and  AFD  reporting  and  fiduciary  requirements  prior  to  project 
implementation.  The  financial  assessment  of  operating  entities  and  the  risk  assessment  and 
management plan are in Supplementary Appendix O. 
 
70. 
Delays  in  implementation  may  result  from  slowness  in  recruiting  consultants  and 
appointing central and provincial project management staff, the resistance of vested interests to 
changes in the organizational structure of service providers (IDMC, IMCs, IMEs, and agriculture 
production  cooperatives),  cumbersome  administrative  processes  related  to  contract  awards, 
and insensitive handling of resettlement. Resettlement and compensation of people affected by 
construction are critical because the commencement of disbursements for civil works contracts 
is conditional upon their prior completion. Project consultants need to help provincial authorities 
complete land acquisition and resettlement on schedule. MARD has experience in and a good 
understanding of government and ADB requirements for resettlement.  
 
71. 
Concerns  exist  about  steadily  declining  water  levels  in  the  Red  River,  which  are  likely 
caused by the operation of the upstream reservoirs, changes in water use, and morphological 
changes in the Red River Delta.  During project preparation an analysis was undertaken of the 
changing  river  regime,  water  levels,  and  river  morphology  in  the  rivers  surrounding  the  BHH 
system.  The  assessment  indicated  that  at  some  locations  the  riverbed  has  dropped  by  an 
average of up to 2 meters. The decrease is most likely the result of morphological changes from 
large  quantities  of  sand  being  mined  and  sediment  retention  in  upstream  reservoirs  disturbing 
the dynamic equilibrium of the river system. The upstream reservoirs will need to release more 
water to achieve the design water level at the BHH Xuan Quan intake during the dry season in 
January  and  February,  when  agricultural  land  is  prepared  for  planting.  With  assistance  from 

 

  

19 

ADB  TA,29  the  Ministry  of  Natural  Resources  and  Environment,  which  has  the  mandate  for 
coordinating river basin water resources management, is revising the Law on Water Resources, 
1998,  which  is  scheduled  for  submission  to  the  National  Assembly  in  May  2011.  This  will 
provide the legal framework for water sharing, water rights and river basin management, which 
will  ultimately  lead  to  agreement  between  the  relevant  ministries  and  agencies  and  the 
establishment of inter-reservoir operation rules optimizing the use of water resources. The study 
of boundary conditions for the BHH system is in Supplementary Appendix P. 
 
An assumption fundamental to the efficient operation of the BHH irrigation and drainage 
72. 
system  is  that  the  government  will  provide  finance  for  the  operation  of  some  key  capital 
investments as well as adequate finance on a timely, recurrent basis for the O&M of these and 
other  capital  investments  financed  under  the  project.  One  crucial  capital  investment  for 
government  financing  outside  the  scope  of  the  project  is  the  cleaning  and  dredging  of  canals 
serving the irrigation and drainage pump stations to be constructed and rehabilitated under the 
project.  Another  key  capital  investment  for  government  financing  outside  the  scope  of  the 
project  is  the  construction  of  the  Cau  Xe  sluice  in  Hai  Duong  Province  to  provide  efficient 
drainage for a large portion of the BHH system and tidal irrigation for parts of Dong Nam Cuu 
An,  Binh  Giang–Bac  Thanh  Mien,  and  Gia  Loc-Tu  Ky.  Finally,  another  requirement  to  ensure 
efficient irrigation of the Gia Thuan area of Bac Ninh Province is to repair or operationalize the 
Nhu  Quynh  pump  station  with  a  capacity  of  at  least  12  m3/second.  Since  the  onset  of  the 
government's  ISF  waiver  policy,  the  irrigation  service  providers  (IDMCs  and  IMCs)  face 
challenges  in  covering  O&M  costs.  However,  the  government  has  made  assurances  that 
adequate budget allocations will be made to provide appropriate service levels that will ensure 
the  sustainability  of  infrastructure  investments  supported  under  the  project  for  a  minimum  30 
years through cost-sharing between the national and provincial governments.

A. 

Development Context and National Goals 

1. 

Population 

SECTOR ANALYSIS 

Viet  Nam’s  population  of  more  than  86  million  (July  2008)1  is  still  predominantly  rural  (63 
1. 
million or 73%)2 and dependent on agriculture for livelihoods and basic needs.3 It is now the 13th 
most populous country in the world. A third of the population lives in the Red–Thai Binh river basin, 
mostly in and around Ha Noi City, which includes the Bac Hung Hai irrigation and drainage system. 
The  contribution  from  agriculture,  forestry,  and  aquaculture  to  the  gross  domestic  product  (GDP) 
was 20.7% in 2009. The sector led in job creation during 2001–2005, adding 4.6 million out of 7.5 
million new jobs.  
 
2. 
According to the median projection, Viet Nam’s population will reach 100 million in the next 
25 years and stabilize at 120 million by the middle of this century. The vast majority of people will 
live in rural areas, where demand for water is estimated to be 3.5 million–4.0 million cubic meters 
(m³) per day by 2010. This year, the urban population may be more than 30 million. This population 
will be supplied with more water per person than rural people, and this will require a daily supply 
capacity  of  4.0  million–4.5  million  m³  per  day,  or  8.0  million–9.0  million  m³  per  day  if  demand  for 
associated industrial production is taken into consideration.  
 

2. 

Economic Growth 

3. 
Viet  Nam  has  been  one  of  Asia’s  fastest-growing  economies  over  the  last  20  years,  with 
real GDP growth averaging 7.4% during 1989–2008. Strong economic growth and improved social 
safety nets have enabled Viet Nam to reduce poverty dramatically. Poverty incidence declined from 
58.1% in 1993 to 15.5% in 2007.4 However, poverty reduction has not been uniform, and pockets of 
extreme poverty persist in rural areas.5 Inequalities in income distribution have increased, reflecting 
higher  growth  in  per  capita  income  in  areas  that  are  rapidly  developing  and  resource-rich  than  in 
areas  that  are  remote,  lack  infrastructure,  have  few  resources,  or  are  vulnerable  to  natural 
disasters.  Rural  areas  have  not  benefited  to  the  same  extent  from  liberalization.  Most  institutions 
serving  rural  communities  have  changed  little  from  an  earlier  era  of  central  control  and  have  not 
benefited from the public administration reforms that have brought more immediate benefits to fast-
developing urban areas. More recently, however, Viet Nam has faced major economic challenges, 
with  yearly  inflation  reaching  23%  in  2008.  Soaring  imports  tripled  the  trade  deficit  in  2007,  while 
the Vietnamese stock market lost 60% of its value. On another front, the global economic crisis has 
hit export  markets. Producers and exporters report that prices for exports such as rubber, coffee, 
pepper, rice, and seafood are falling. Other major exports also face difficulties as Viet Nam's main 
export markets tighten their belts. All of this points to slower economic growth than projected in the 
immediate future at least.  
 
4. 
Nonetheless, the current structure of the national economy is highly indicative of a rapidly 
developing country soon to become middle income. The agriculture sector in the composition of the 
GDP  has  dropped  from  80%–90%  at  its  peak  to  the  current  level  of  about  20%,  though  this  still 
represents  significant  economic  activity.  The  drop  has  been  caused  chiefly  by  strong  growth  in
