reduced demand for irrigation water.  
 
5. 
One  of  the  greatest  pressures  on  water  resources  and  the  water  sector  comes  from  the 
strength  of  economic  development  in  Viet  Nam  and  the  changing  structure  of  the  economy.  This 
growth  increasingly  consumes  natural  resources,  requires  reliable  water  supplies,  attracts 
significant  populations,  and,  most  importantly,  generates  considerable  polluted  wastewater  and 
other wastes.  
 
The 5-year socioeconomic development plans are development strategies, but they also set 
6. 
development and investment targets and combine (often without prioritizing) proposals contained in 
sector  plans  (e.g.,  transport,  industry,  education,  and  health).  The  socioeconomic  development 
plans  are  the  main  pillar  of  Viet  Nam's  strategic  planning  architecture.  Sector  development  plans 
present  targets  and  strategies  for  the  outputs  of  individual  sectors,  e.g.,  water  supply,  urban 
transport,  main  industries,  and  agriculture.  Sector  plans  are  also  prepared  for  infrastructure,  e.g., 
transport, water supply, etc. At this stage, these plans remain a top–down process and reportedly 
there is a lack of cross-sectoral cooperation during their formulation. Plans are prepared by a small 
number  of  central  government  planning  institutes  with  limited  public  participation.  In  most  cases, 
plans  are  not  consistent  with  the  availability  of  resources,  and  there  is  a  general  tendency  to 
optimistically  approve  plans  and  related  lists  of  projects  in  the  hope  that  funding  will  become 
available. 
 
B. 

Agriculture Sector Situation 

7. 
Prior to 2009 the country’s agriculture sector had grown steadily at an annual rate of about 
4%,  despite  generally  weak  international  commodity  prices.  Crops  constitute  59%  of  the  total 
agriculture sector production value, followed by fisheries at 19%, livestock at 17%, and forestry at 
5%. The development of the livestock industry has been vigorous in recent years. Despite growth 
in  crop  and livestock  production,  however,  the  incidence  of  poverty  remains  higher  in  rural  areas 
than in urban,6 and private sector investment remains low. 
 
8. 
Agriculture sector growth over the past decade, particularly in crops, can be attributed to a 
combination of (i) the government’s market-oriented economic policy, which was launched in 1986; 
(ii)  increased  public  investment  in  irrigation  systems;  and  (iii)  increased  use  of  land,  labor,  and 
agrochemicals and fertilizers, particularly in rice production. Continued heavy reliance on increased 
public  spending  on  irrigation  systems,  however,  will  not  be  able  to  sustain  agricultural  growth  in 
light of the diminishing marginal returns from new irrigation investments and the substantial cost of 
operating and maintaining these systems. Moreover, further increases in agricultural production are 
now  being  constrained  by  rising  input  prices,  declining  revenues  from  rice  exports  due  to  weak 
international prices, limits on the productivity of agricultural inputs and financial capacity of farmers, 
and limits on further expansion of the rural labor force and land for agriculture. 
 
9. 
Agriculture provides employment for 57% of the country’s workforce, mainly in rural areas, 
where  73%  of  the  population  resides,  including  70%  of  the  poor.7  An  alternative  strategy  for 
sustainable agricultural growth is needed to support the country’s economic growth and attainment 
of its poverty-reduction targets. This strategy will require the development of (i) diversified farming 
systems  that  are  adaptable  to  varied  agro-ecological  conditions  and  (ii)  more  locally  driven,

10.  With the population growing at 1.4% per year and the standard of living improving, it is likely 
that national rice consumption will increase by up to 2% annually from about 20 million tons of rice 
per year. If there is no increase in production, it will take only about 10–12 years before the present 
surplus  of  4–5  million  tons  per  year,  which  is  now  exported,  would  be  required  for  domestic 
consumption.  Bearing  in  mind  that  the  area  of  paddy  land  has  decreased  in  recent  years  with 
diversification to aquaculture and other crops, as well as with industrial and housing development, 
it will be essential to increase yields to meet demand. Increasing the irrigated area and improving 
water use efficiency would contribute to increased yields. 
 
C. 

Water Sector Situation 

11. 
An  objective  of  the  National  Water Resources Strategy  toward  2020  is  water  allocation  to 
ensure  the  efficient  exploitation  of  10.5  million  ha  of  annual  and  perennial  crops,  and  thereby 
produce  39–40  million  tons  of  rice  equivalent  per  year.  That  figure  is  construed  to  mean  paddy 
production of around 34 million tons per year in view of the “agricultural restructuring” plan of the 
Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (MARD). That much production has been achieved 
and  maintained  since  2002.  Priorities  in  the  development  and  management  of  agricultural  water 
control  systems  should  change  in  view  of  market  demand  and  be  reflected  in  national  water 
resources management. 
 
At present, 80.6 billion m3 of water is used each year. By 2020, this is expected to increase 
12. 
to about 120.0 billion m3, an increase of 48%. Of this, water use for irrigation is expected to grow by 
about 30%, for industry by almost 190%, for urban supplies by 150%, and for aquaculture by 90%. 
By 2020, although irrigation water use will grow the most in absolute terms, its proportional share 
will have declined from 82% to 72%. Hydropower is not included as it does not generally consume 
water, though it can significantly change flow patterns, as is the case in the Red River Basin.  
 
The  recently  concluded  water  sector  review8  reveals  that  the  water  sector  in  Viet  Nam  is 
13. 
facing an immense crisis that requires immediate action on many fronts. However, few people yet 
realize  that  this  is  the  case,  let  alone  the  extent  or  scale  of  the  problem.  The  water  sector  is 
besieged  with  major  issues  ranging  from  lack  of  data  to  poor  financial  viability,  the  lack  of  water 
rights,  and  serious  pollution.  MARD  has  drawn  attention  to  the  inequities  of  development.  At 
present,  industrial  and  urban  areas  dump  polluted  wastewater  directly  into  irrigation  and  natural 
river  systems,  harming  environmental  health  in  general  and  harming  the  quality  of  irrigation 
systems for agriculture and the outputs of fisheries and forests.  
 
14. 
A  clear  conclusion  from  the  water  sector  review  is  that  fundamental  changes  are  urgently 
required, as is a significant cultural shift, inside the government and out, if these approaches are to 
succeed and the benefits realized. Traditional thinking and practices must be transformed and new 
concepts embraced. This equally applies to international development partners.  
 
D. 

Irrigation Subsector 

15. 
Irrigation has long been the pillar of the rural community. Strong irrigation development over 
many  years  has  ensured  food  security  and  turned  Viet  Nam  into  a  major  exporter  of  rice.  Water 
supply  for  growing  paddy  rice  is  at  the  very  core  of  most  rural  communities.  As  such,  irrigation 
management is steeped in tradition. However, since the irrigation service fee (ISF) was abolished,

 28 

Appendix 2 

irrigation water has been provided free of charge, further entrenching that tradition. Irrigation is now 
in effect a means of providing social services to most of the rural populace. Today, irrigation supply 
is  generally  inefficient,  its  infrastructure  old  and  dilapidated,  totally  reliant  on  state  and  official 
development  assistance  funds  to  keep  going.  Most  systems  operate  on  a  shoestring;  all  are 
progressively deteriorating, despite some rehabilitation funded by official development assistance; 
and some will eventually cease to be viable in part or full. Irrigation reform is a difficult dilemma for 
the government. 
 
16. 
Irrigation  reforms  have  been  slow.  Farmers  still  have  little  say  in  system  management. 
Irrigation  systems  are  set  up  for  paddy  rice,  with  water  supplied  by  irrigation  and  drainage 
management  companies  (IDMCs)  and  irrigation  management  companies  (IMCs)  to  meet  these 
water  requirements.  Crop  diversification  is  difficult  as  supply  is  top–down  for  paddy  rice  and  not 
farmer  driven.  Even  though  there  have  been  some  participatory  irrigation  management  (PIM) 
successes, with irrigation water now free, there is little incentive for farmers to get involved. For the 
future,  the  government  will  need  to  make  hard  decisions  on  the  extent  to  which  traditional 
approaches  are  to  continue,  with  irrigation  water  supply  used  as  a  means  of  delivering  social 
services,  compared  with  the  extent  that  major  reforms  could  create  over  time  an  innovative  and 
progressive irrigation sector. 
 
17. 
MARD has the primary responsibility for irrigation management. The Water Department in 
MARD and its associated institutes (including the Institute for Water Resources Planning) lead the 
planning  and  development  of  major  agricultural  infrastructure.  MARD  controls  12  general 
corporations  with  a  total  of  317  companies.  The  number  of  state-owned  businesses  in  the  sector 
has  remained  about  the  same  during  2000–2003.  These  enterprises  are  characterized  as  having 
low efficiency. At present, there are 110 IMCs employing over 22,500 people. Three of the IDMCs 
are  under  the  direct control  of  MARD,  including  one  for  the  Bac  Hung  Hai  system.  The  IMCs  are 
under provincial control. In terms of the number of staff per thousand of hectares irrigated, the Red 
River Delta has the highest ratio (10.5), suggesting inefficient service delivery. 
 
Local participation through PIM and water users groups is seen as vital to ensure service 
18. 
quality and the efficient use of water resources in irrigation systems. PIM pilots have demonstrated 
that it can bring significant improvement in the effectiveness of water management. However, the 
expansion  of  PIM  application  has  been  slow  for  reasons  concerning  governance  at  all  levels  and 
water user awareness and ability. 
 
19. 
Until  very  recently,  individual  farmers  paid  an  ISF  to  cover  a  proportion  of  the  operations 
and  maintenance  costs  associated  with  irrigation  water  delivery  by  both  IDMCs  and  water  users 
associations  (WUAs).  Although  not  adequate  to  cover  operations  and  maintenance,  these  fees 
provided a substantial proportion of the budget for provincial IMCs and centrally controlled IDMCs. 
In  2006,  D935.3  billion  in  ISFs  was  collected,  of  which  68%  was  allocated  to  IMCs  and  32%  to 
WUAs.  Fees  were  reported  to  cover  70%–80%  of  IMC  running  costs.  In  2008,  however,  this  fee 
was abolished.9 
 
20. 

Irrigation issues include the following: 
(i) 

Planners  need  to  look  at  whether  the  efficiency  of  existing  infrastructure  and 
development  can  be  improved  before  planning  new  developments,  and  whether 
agricultural  expansion  is  the  most  appropriate  development  path  for  the  basin 
community. 
Many hydraulic works are now 30–40 years old, and little significant rehabilitation or 
refurbishment  has  been  undertaken.  This  results  in  inefficient  water  delivery. 
Several causes of operations and maintenance inefficiencies have been identified.

One of the main reasons for the degraded state of irrigation infrastructure is the lack 
of sustainable financing. State budgets are insufficient to satisfy major refurbishment 
demands,  and  provincial  budgets  are  even  less  capable  of  providing  such 
allocations. The abolition of the ISF has removed significant income from IDMCs. 
Poor  water  quality  poses  a  public  health  risk  when  used  to  irrigate  food  crops, 
particularly  from  excessive  use  of  fertilizers  and  pesticides,  but  also  reduces  crop 
yields. 
Institutional, legal, and policy frameworks suffer from gaps, overlaps, inconsistency, 
and duplication. The regulatory environment creates uncertainties in mandates and 
functions  and  promotes  both  inaction  and  territorial  disputes.  The  lines  remain 
blurred  between  state  management  of  water  resources  and  state  management  of 
irrigation and drainage. 
Communication  and  coordination  is  poor  in  the  IDMCs  among  boards  of  directors, 
technical  water  management,  finance  and  administration  departments,  and  lower 
management  (IMCs,  irrigation  management  enterprises,  and  agriculture  production 
cooperatives). 
A  shift  in  irrigation  management  philosophy  and  practice  will  require  substantial 
changes  to  the  mix  of  skills  nationally  and  provincially  and  in  IDMCs,  IMCs, 
agriculture  production  cooperatives,  and  WUA,  which  calls  for  strategy  and 
curriculum development at Water Resources University. 

 
In  2004,  MARD  launched,  with  financial  assistance  from  the  World  Bank,  the  Vietnam 
21. 
Water Resources Assistance Project,10 a national program to rehabilitate six of the largest irrigation 
systems in the country and establish a service-oriented approach wherein provincial agencies and 
the water users are empowered to jointly manage irrigation systems. In this way, MARD sought to 
raise  the  efficiency  of  water  delivery  and  realize  the  full  potential  of  its  investments.  In  the  same 
year,  MARD  approved  and  issued  guidelines11  for  establishing,  strengthening,  and  developing 
WUAs,  which  facilitated  the  implementation  of  several  PIM  projects  with  international  funding. 
MARD concurrently established a program to accelerate the implementation of PIM with the aim of 
transferring  responsibility  for  operations  and  maintenance  to  farmers.  This  is  being  piloted  under 
the Second Red River Basin Sector Project.12

SUMMARY POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL STRATEGY 
 

Country and Project Title: Viet Nam-Strengthening Water Management and Irrigation Systems Rehabilitation Project 

Lending/Financing Modality:  Project

Southeast Asia Department/

I. 

POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

 
A.  Link to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
In its Socioeconomic Development Plan for 2006–2010, Viet Nam’s guiding poverty reduction strategy paper, the government 
sets out its strategy to reach its goal of becoming an industrialized nation by 2020, with poverty alleviation as an underlying 
condition for achieving this result.  An important part of Viet Nam’s strategy is economic diversification, including reducing the 
percentage of the population dependent on agriculture for their livelihood from 85% to 50% while at the same time increasing 
the  productivity  of  agriculture.  Strengthening  the  water  resources  sector  is  a  key  element  of  the  strategy  for  supporting  an 
increasingly urbanized economy while at the same time ensuring sustainable development of agriculture for economic growth, 
poverty  reduction,  and  food  security.  Water  resources  management  is  also  central  to  reducing  vulnerability  to  floods  and 
droughts,  which  are  key  obstacles  to  poverty  reduction,  according  to  the  Socioeconomic  Development  Plan.  In  its  country 
partnership  strategy,  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  commits  to  supporting  key  elements  of  the  government’s 
Socioeconomic Development Plan with a particular focus on promoting pro-poor, business-led economic growth that is based 
on the sustainable use of the environment and promotes social inclusion and gender equality. 
Viet  Nam’s  National  Water  Resources  Strategy,  2006–2020  highlights  that  growth  in  population  and  in  the  gross  domestic 
product is straining water resources. According to the National Water Resources Strategy, safe access to water for the poor is 
a central priority, and management of this resource must contribute to pro-poor and sustainable socioeconomic development. 
The  strategy  recognizes  peoples’  right  to  water  to  meet  their  livelihood  needs  but  at  the  same  time  their  obligation  to  be 
involved in its efficient management.  
The project will improve the livelihoods and increase the incomes of 2.8 million people across four provinces that depend on 
water from the Bac Hung Hai irrigation and drainage system for agricultural production, domestic use, and small industries. It 
will  improve  the  skills  of  future  water  resources  engineers  and  technicians  through  improvements  in  the  Water  Resource 
University (WRU) curriculum and facilities. The project approach is in line with ADB’s water sector review,a which highlights 
the importance of a dual approach of strengthening institutional capacity for water resources management and rehabilitating 
irrigation  systems  to  meet  the  demands  of  an  expanding  economy.  The  water  sector  review  recognizes  the  need  for 
investments  to  upgrade  multipurpose  irrigation  and  drainage  systems  and  (i)  reduce  water  production  costs  by  upgrading 
hydraulic works, (ii) control flooding and reduce disaster risks, (iii) facilitate diversification from paddy rice production to other 
crops as well as improve drainage systems for paddy rice, and (iv) promote savings in the system-wide use of irrigation water 
to allow water use for other community needs. In line with the water sector review, the project has developed an approach to 
rehabilitating  the  Bac  Hung  Hai  (BHH)  system  that  emphasizes  improving  efficiency  and  reducing  pollution  in  the  usage  of 
existing  irrigation  water  rather  than  substantially  increasing  water  intake.  The  mix  of  investment  options  addresses  both 
irrigation  and  drainage  needs  for  rice  production  as  well  as  for  diversification  to  higher-value  crops,  an  important  way  for 
farmers to increase incomes. Protecting people and their assets from flooding in rural and newly developing urban areas is an 
important factor that has guided the choice of investment options. 

 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
1.  Key Issues  
The classification is based on the main outputs of the proposed project: (i) strengthened capacity for  water-related services 
delivery  in  the  country  through  the  construction  of  a  new  campus  and  curriculum  development  for  WRU,  (ii)  improved 
management of irrigation and drainage management companies, and (iii) an upgraded BHH irrigation and drainage system to 
improve livelihoods and increase incomes for 2.8 million people.  
The project will create enabling conditions for economic growth and the sustainable use of water resources in the Red River 
Delta, which is a key element of the Government of Viet Nam’s strategy to reduce poverty. The Red River Delta, in which the 
Bac Hung Hai system is located, is not a geographic focus for targeted poverty reduction programs, as it is has lower poverty 
rates than other parts of Viet Nam. However, as a region with highly productive agricultural land and a growing industrial base 
the Red River Delta is important to assuring domestic food supply and is a key driving force of the country’s economy. The 
project  will  contribute  to  development  and  poverty  reduction  through  (i)  creating  conditions  to  improve  the  knowledge  and 
skills base of engineers and technicians in the water resources sector, (ii) improving agricultural productivity and supporting 
farmers’  diversification  of  production  through  upgraded  hydraulic  equipment  and  more  efficient  systems  for  controlling  the 
timing and allocation of irrigation water, (iii) saving irrigation water that can be allocated to other community livelihood needs, 
(iv) promoting institutional arrangements that enhance water user participation in irrigation and drainage system management, 
and (v) greater protection of people and their assets from flooding. 

 

 46 

Appendix 9 

2. Design Features 
The  project  includes  measures  for  (i)  enhancing  the  responsiveness  of  irrigation  and  drainage  management  systems  to 
farmers’  actual  needs;  (ii)  ensuring  that  poor  and  vulnerable  households  affected  by  project  activities,  such  as  land 
acquisition, will improve their socioeconomic condition through relocation and income restoration programs; and (iii) creating 
conditions  whereby  areas  underserved  by  irrigation  services  can  benefit  from  water  savings  and  improved  efficiency  in  the 
allocation of water.  

II. 

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

1. Findings of Social Analysis 
The  direct  beneficiaries  of  the  BHH  component  are  (i)  560,000  people  who  will  benefit  from  increased  household  incomes 
from  improved  irrigation  and  (ii)  1.9  million  people  who  will  benefit  from  improved  flood  protection.  Indirectly,  2.8  million 
women and men living in the four provinces covered by the system, which includes all or parts of the provinces of Hung Yen, 
Hai Duong, Bac Ninh, and Ha Noi, will benefit from improvements in system management and performance for both irrigation 
and drainage. The primary beneficiaries of the WRU component are 13,400 future students. These students will benefit from 
(i) improved teaching and learning facilities for faculty members and students, at least 26% of whom will be women based on 
present  trends;  (ii)  dormitory  space  for  30%  of  the  student  population,  with  50%  of  this  space  reserved  for  women  to 
encourage them to study at the new campus; and (iii) accommodation for ethnic minority students and other disadvantaged 
groups, which can be expanded as the student population grows at the new campus. Other direct beneficiaries of the WRU 
component are 37,777 local residents who will have access to new job and business opportunities. There are no indigenous 
people  in  the  project  area.  Chuong  My  District  has  a  population  of  290,449  who  will  indirectly  benefit  from  the  income-
generating opportunities the university community will create in the area. This local population will also benefit from increased 
education opportunities for youths. 
 
Bac Hung Hai. The BHH irrigation and drainage system is on the Red River Delta of Viet Nam. The Red River Delta is among 
the regions that have seen the greatest reductions in poverty over the last 13 years, from 62.7% in 1993 to 8.8% in 2006. The 
2007 poverty rate in the target provinces are 8.4% in Ha Noi, 7.7% in Bac Ninh, 13.4% in Hai Duong, and 9.2% in Hung Yen, 
which compare favorably with the national rate in 2007 of 14.8%. This lower rate of poverty reflects the region’s being one of 
the hubs of the country’s growing economy. Nonetheless, the region faces economic challenges. In 2008, unemployment in 
the Red River Delta area was higher than other regions of the country, at 5.35% compared with the national rate of 4.65%.   

The BHH provinces are among the top 8 of Viet Nam’s 61 provinces in terms of population density. Despite lower poverty, this 
area currently faces social and economic challenges related to the rapid pace of transition from a primarily agricultural area to 
a mixture of agriculture, industrial zones, and urban areas. Most of the people in BHH are employed in agriculture, ranging 
from 60% to 98% across project districts. Among agricultural households, 44% are self-employed on their own farms. Land-
holdings  are  very  small,  with  more  than  half  measuring  less  than  0.2  hectares  and  fewer  than  3%  being  more  than  0.5 
hectares.  People  in  this  area  will  depend  increasingly  on  services  and  industry  for  continued  economic  growth,  and  the 
demands on water systems to meet multiple purposes will expand.  
Along  with  improvements  in  water  services  that  bring  social  and  economic  benefits,  the  project  component  on  improved 
management  is  designed  to  strengthen  water  users  associations  and  empower  water  users,  both  women  and  men,  to  take 
part in decisions that affect their well-being and strengthen system sustainability. 

Water  Resources  University.  WRU  currently  has  a  student  population  of  10,000.  Close  to  2,500  students  enrolled  as 
undergraduates in 2009, and 200 as graduate students, which was a 20% increase over the previous year. The student body 
is  expected  to  grow  to  13,000  by  2012.  The  new  campus  site  is  in  Chuong  My  District  of  Ha  Noi,  which  is  a  largely  rural 
setting 15 kilometers from the city center. The site covers two communes and one town that have a total population of 37,777.  
Poverty rates are 13.4% in Tien Phuong Commune, 17.7% in Phung Chau, and 6.8% in Chuc Son Town. According to the 
socioeconomic survey, 79% of people farm as their main occupation, and operating a business or trade is the second most 
common occupation. Fewer than 3% of those surveyed have not completed primary school, and half have completed lower 
secondary  education.    Most  households  have  clean  drinking  water  and  electricity,  and  less  than  1%  reported  facing  food 
shortages in the year.  

The new WRU campus will have positive social impacts, as it will provide better conditions for students and teachers for study 
and research. The new campus with provide improved accommodation and sanitation, which will benefit poor students, 
especially females. Indirect benefits include the new jobs the campus site will create for local residents both during and after 
construction. 

The negative social impact of the WRU component will be loss of livelihoods for people affected by land acquisition. A total of 
761  households  are  affected  by  land  acquisition,  including  25  households  that  will  need  to  relocate  their  residences.  A  full 
resettlement  plan  for  the  WRU  component  has  been  prepared  to  ensure  that  all  affected  households  will  restore  their 
livelihoods and living standards to pre-project levels. The resettlement plan includes an income-restoration program that will 
include providing household members who lose agricultural land with jobs generated by the new WRU campus.

C.   Gender and Development 

1.  Key Issues  
Women are now a higher percentage of agriculture workers than men in the BHH provinces. For example, in Bac Ninh 40% of 
the employed population of agricultural households are men, compared with 60% women. Women are important contributors 
to  family  income.  The  socioeconomic  survey  shows  that  women’s  occupational  profile  is  similar  to  that  of  men,  with  most 
working in agriculture, followed by operating a business. One notable difference is that women heads of household are more 
likely than male heads to have a secondary occupation as hired labor, with as many as 64% reporting a secondary occupation 
in this area. Women heads of household are less likely to have completed lower secondary or upper secondary school.  

The gender  analysis shows that  women and men share  many farm tasks, as  well  as  off-farm  work.  However,  women have 
much  more  responsibility  for  household  work  such  as  cooking  and  cleaning.  The  surveys  show  that  women  are  less  likely 
than  men  to  participate  in  community  meetings.  Given  women’s  important  role  in  agriculture,  the  inclusion  of  women 
representatives as stakeholders for consultation and decision-making on the management, and operations and maintenance 
of the BHH system is essential to ensuring that the views of the majority of stakeholders are included in system development. 
Women’s participation in resettlement is also critical to the effective implementation of plans. 

2.  Key Actions 
Measures  included  in  the  design  to  promote  gender  equality  and  women’s  empowerment—access  to  and  use  of  relevant 
services, resources, assets, or opportunities and participation in decision-making process: 
  Other actions/measures      

  No action/measure 

  Gender plan      

The design of the WRU campus includes the following measures to integrate gender: (i) an allocation of budget and space for 
the development of dormitories to house at least one-third of the student population, with 50% of the dormitory space to be 
designated for use by females, as on-site lodging will make attendance at university more viable for women; (ii) the inclusion 
of  gender  education  in  the  curriculum  addressing  water  use  and  society;  and  (iii)  consultation  with  women  students  and 
faculty  on  the  campus  site,  design,  buildings,  and  equipment  to  ensure  women’s  needs  are  addressed,  with  all  such 
consultations  including  30%–40%  of  women  stakeholders.  The  BHH  system  will  introduce  the  actions  to  promote  women’s 
equality in water resources management, which will include (i) the allocation of resources for a gender specialist to increase 
women’s  participation  in  irrigation  and  drainage  management;  (ii)  consultations  with  women’s  groups,  through  the  women’s 
union, and through focus groups of women at the village level on how improvements in irrigation services management can 
address  women’s  needs  and  priorities;  (iii)  women  to  be  50%  of  the  beneficiaries  consulted  on  vision  and  strategy 
development  of  BHH  to  ensure  that  women’s  needs  and  priorities  related  to  water  use  are  incorporated  in  the  vision  and 
strategy; (iv) gender sensitization for departments of agriculture and rural development, irrigation and drainage management 
companies, and irrigation management committees to facilitate addressing the lack of representation of women in the water 
resources  sector  compared  with  the  high  number  of  female  farmers;  (v)  identification  of  female  staff  in  departments  of 
agriculture and rural development and the BHH system to take active roles in project and training plans for enhancing their

SUMMARY OF RESETTLEMENT ISSUES 

Introduction 

A. 
 
1. 
The  project  will  support  the  government’s  efforts  to  increase  the  number  of  qualified 
agriculture-related  water  management  engineers,  improve  the  governance  and  management  of 
irrigation systems, increase agricultural production, and improve the productivity of project areas to 
increase  the  incomes  of  poor  farmers.  The  project  will  construct  a  new  campus  for  the  Water 
Resources University on a site in Chuong My District of Ha Noi City, approximately 15 kilometers 
from  the  existing  campus.  Under  two  other  components,  the  project  will  construct  new 
infrastructure  and  upgrade  existing  irrigation  infrastructure  in  the  Bac  Hung  Hai  irrigation  and 
drainage system. 
 
The resettlement plans' legal basis, policy and principles, public consultation and grievance 
2. 
process,  and  implementation  and  monitoring  process  follow  the  provisions  of  the  resettlement 
framework  as  summarized  below.  The  resettlement  framework  is  in  Supplementary  Appendix  K. 
The resettlement plans are in Supplementary Appendix L. 
 
B. 

Resettlement Effects 

3. 
The  Water  Resources  University  campus  component  will  require  the  recovery  of  57.3 
hectares.  The  land  acquisition  will  affect  776  households  across  the  three  communes  of  Chuong 
My District. A total of 739 households will lose agriculture land, 92% of them losing 10% or more. A 
total  of  40  households  will  lose  residential  land.  Of  these,  25  have  a  dwelling  on  the  land  and  7 
operate a business from their residence.  

4. 
For the Bac Hung Hai system, the project will finance the rehabilitation and construction of 
irrigation and drainage works, including natural disaster risk-reduction measures, in 11 subprojects. 
These  subprojects  are  estimated  to  affect  700  households,  200–300  of  which  will  be  severely 
affected,  with  approximately  20  households  requiring  relocation.  People  with  agricultural  land  or 
aquaculture  surface  areas  will  require  compensation  for  the  land,  assets,  and  crops  and 
aquaculture  products  affected  at  the  time  of  acquisition,  as  well  as  support  for  livelihood 
restoration. People living and doing business in areas where houses must be removed will require 
support for relocation, compensation for land and structures, and income restoration. 
 
C. 

Purpose of the Resettlement Framework 

5. 
The  resettlement  framework  is  the  guiding  document  for  preparing  and  implementing 
resettlement  plans  for  any  component  or  subproject  that  entails  involuntary  resettlement.  The 
resettlement framework identifies the key issues to address in reconciling the requirements of the 
Involuntary  Resettlement  Policy  (1995)  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  with  national  and 
provincial  government  policies  related  to  compensation  for  recovered  assets  and  adversely 
affected incomes, including measures for ensuring that affected people or households are able to 
restore their standards of living to at least their pre-project levels. 

6. 
The  resettlement  framework  sets  out  the  objectives,  principles,  criteria  of  eligibility  to 
entitlements,  modes  of  compensation,  participation  and  consultation  procedures,  and  grievance 
redress mechanisms. It also sets out the steps in preparing and implementing resettlement plans.   
 

1. 

Legal Basis, Policy, and Principles 

 
7. 
The legal and policy framework for compensation, resettlement, and rehabilitation under the 
project  is  defined  by  the  laws  and  regulations  of  the  government  and  ADB  policies.  In  case  of 
discrepancies  between  the  borrower’s  laws,  regulations,  and  procedures  and  ADB's  policies  and 
requirements,  ADB's  policies  and  requirements  will  prevail.  Resettlement  is  based  on  a  set  of 

 

 

 Appendix 10 

50 
 
principles to ensure fairness and due process; that affected people get the maximum benefits that 
are  their  due,  regardless  of  their  land  tenure  status;  and  that  special  treatment  is  accorded  poor 
and vulnerable households to improve their situation following resettlement. 
 

2. 

Project Entitlements for Affected Households 

 
8. 
The  project  entitlements  developed  and  presented  in  the  resettlement  framework 
correspond  to  the  impacts  identified  during  the  census  and  inventory  of  losses.  The  entitlements 
include  an  income-restoration  strategy  that  has  been  designed  following  consultations  with  the 
project  management  units,  district  and  commune  authorities,  and  affected  people.  An  important 
element  of  the  income  restoration  strategy  is  ensuring  that  affected  people  are  in  a  position  to 
benefit from the new economic opportunities created by the construction of subprojects. 
 

3. 

Participation, Disclosure, and Grievance Redress 

 
9. 
Consultations,  public  meetings,  and  village  discussions  with  affected  people  and  local 
officials were carried out during resettlement planning. Project policies and options with regard to 
relocation and income restoration were discussed during the meetings. Concerns and suggestions 
raised by affected people were elicited and incorporated into the resettlement plan. The grievance 
mechanism is designed to ensure that affected people’s concerns and grievances are addressed 
and resolved in a timely and satisfactory manner. Affected people will be made fully aware of their 
rights  verbally  and  in  writing  during  consultation  and  surveys,  as  well  as  at  the  time  of 
compensation.  
 

4. 

Implementation 

 
10. 
The Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, through the project management unit of 
the  Central  Project  Office,  will  assure  coordination  for  the  implementation  of  resettlement  plans. 
The  Ministry  of  Agriculture  and  Rural  Development  will,  through  the  central  project  management 
unit  (CPMU),  coordinate  with  the  provincial  people’s  committee  and  instruct  the  project 
management units to ensure that compensation and assistance are administered according to the 
provisions of this resettlement plan. A provincial resettlement and compensation board and district 
resettlement and compensation board with representation of affected people will be established to 
administer  the  compensation  process.  During  implementation,  external  monitors  will  be  hired  to 
ensure compensation is administered in line with approved resettlement plans.  
 

5. 

Monitoring 

11. 
The  resettlement  framework  includes  provisions  for  both  internal  and  external  monitoring 
during resettlement. Primary responsibility for internal monitoring lies with the CPMU as the project 
implementing  agency.  The  CPMU  will  be  responsible  for  overseeing  the  formation,  function,  and 
activities of each of the provincial and district bodies responsible for resettlement. The CPMU will 
engage  external  monitors  to  conduct  external  monitoring  of  resettlement  plan  implementation  for 
both components of the project. The purpose of external monitoring will be to assess whether the 
resettlement plan has been implemented as planned, entitlements have been delivered and meet 
intentions, and affected people are able to restore their living conditions, livelihoods, and incomes 
to pre-subproject levels and, if not, recommend remedial actions to assist them. 

6. 

Resettlement Budget 

 
A resettlement budget is required for all resettlement activities, including compensation for 
12. 
land acquisition, affected assets, administrative costs, monitoring, income restoration, establishing 
a  resettlement  site,  etc.,  and  included  in  project  cost.  This  cost  is  covered  by  the  government 
budget. The full entitlement matrix is in Supplementary Appendix K.

SUMMARY INITIAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXAMINATION 
 

A. 

Introduction 

1. 
The initial environmental examination (IEE) of the proposed subprojects for the Bac Hung 
Hai (BHH) irrigation and drainage system and the new campus for the Water Resources University 
(WRU)  was  carried  out  to  identify  and  screen  potential  adverse  environmental  impacts  on  the 
physical and social environment, recommend measures to mitigate them, and provide guidance on 
appropriate  institutional  arrangements  for  environmental  monitoring.  The  IEEs  were  carried  out 
following  the  environmental  policy  and  guidelines  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  and  the 
environmental policies and regulations of the government.  
 
B. 

Description of the Project 

1. 

WRU Campus  

2. 
The site for the WRU campus is 57.3 hectares of agricultural land in Chuong My District of 
Ha  Noi  City.  The  infrastructure  investments  for  phase  1  comprise  the  following  facilities:  (i) 
classrooms  for  seven  faculties  with  a  total  capacity  of  9,930  students;  (ii)  lecture  halls  with  a 
capacity  of  4,500  students;  (iii)  faculty  libraries  and  administration  offices;  (iv)  laboratories;  (v) 
dormitories for 4,022 students; and (vi) outside parking for 125 cars. 
 

2. 

Bac Hung Hai System 

3. 
The BHH system is located in the heart of the Red River Delta. It is the oldest, largest, and 
most important system in the region. Two types of subprojects have been proposed: (i) eight new 
pumping stations and (ii) two existing pumping stations to be rehabilitated. 
 
C. 

Description of the Environment 

4. 
The project area for both the WRU campus and the BHH system subprojects has a tropical 
monsoon climate. Two main seasons can be distinguished: the cool, dry season from October to 
April  and  the  hot,  rainy  season  from  May  to  September.  The  average  temperature  in  the  project 
area is 23ºC, and the mean annual rainfall is 1,700–1,800 millimeters. There are no official nature 
reserves or  protected areas, and there are no  endangered species in the project area. The main 
crops are cassava, maize, peanuts, rice, and sweet potato. 
 

1. 

WRU Campus  

The project area is affected by the hydrological regime of the Day River, a tributary of the 
5. 
Red  River.  In  the  dry  season  the  water  is  contaminated  by  organic  substances  from  industries, 
small handicraft industries, farms, and domestic waste. Groundwater resources in the project area 
are  abundant  and  of  good  quality,  except  in  some  areas  in  Chuong  My  District  that  are  polluted 
with arsenic. 
 
6. 
The  WRU  subproject  area  is  near  the  Tram  and  Tram  Gian  pagodas,  which  are  national 
heritage  sites  of  interest  to  Vietnamese  nationals  and  foreign  tourists.  The  design  of  the  WRU 
campus includes a buffer zone between them and the campus. 
 
7. 
Only  a  small  percentage  of  the  households  have  access  to  piped  water.  Domestic  and 
industrial wastewater is discharged without treatment into ponds, lakes, and canals, contaminating 
them. About 20% of the households have their garbage collected, while the remainder burn, bury, 
or dump their garbage in nearby fields. 
 

 

 52 

Appendix 11 

2. 

Bac Hung Hai Area 

The hydrology of the entire BHH system is dominated by its bordering rivers: the Red River 
8. 
to the east, Duong to the north, Thai Binh to the west, and Luoc to the south. The quality of water in 
the  main  canals  and  rivers  does  not  meet  standards  for  domestic  water  supply  but  meets  the 
standard  for  irrigation  water.  Groundwater  reserves  are  abundant  and  used  mainly  for  industrial 
and domestic water supply. Groundwater quality is good except in some locations contaminated by 
organic substances and heavy metals (especially in handicraft villages). Salinity is reportedly high 
in Gia Binh and Luong Tai districts. 
 
9. 
Only  a  small  percentage  of  the  households  have  access  to  piped  water  (8%–13%). 
Domestic  and  industrial  wastewater  is  discharged  into  ponds,  lakes,  and  irrigation  and  drainage 
canals without sufficient treatment. A number of communes have communal sewage and drainage 
systems  and  have  an  organized  system  for  solid  waste  collection  (70%–75%).  Households  that 
have pit latrines average between 98.3%–99.9%. 
 
D. 

Forecasting Environmental Impacts and Mitigation Measures 

10. 
The negative environmental impacts expected from the realization of the WRU campus and 
the BHH system subprojects in the different projects phases and the proposed mitigation measures 
are listed below. All identified impacts are small or moderate, and none is significant. Most adverse 
impacts are temporary and can be mitigated.  
 
11. 
A  positive  environmental  impact  that  can  be  expected  from  the  project  is  the  intensified 
effect of flushing by larger volumes of intake in the BHH system and larger volumes of discharge 
out of the system. Intensified flushing may have a positive effect on the quality of surface waters in 
the  BHH  system.  Improving  drainage  capacity  can  resolve  water-logging  in  the  BHH  system  with 
an  improvement  of  hygienic-sanitary  conditions.  The  WRU  campus  will  bring  modern  education 
and research facilities that provide capable human resources for improved management of water 
resources in the future.

E. 

Institutional Requirements and Environmental Monitoring Plan 

12. 
The  Central  Project  Office  will  be  the  executing  agency  for  the  project.  A  project 
management unit (PMU) will be established for WRU and for each province in the BHH system to 
manage and monitor day-to-day implementation. The supervision and monitoring of project-related 
resettlement  and  environmental  activities  during  the  preconstruction,  construction,  and  operation 
phases will be the responsibility of these PMUs. For that purpose, an environmental management 
unit  will  be  established  in  the  PMU.  The  environmental  management  plans  (EMPs)  will  cover 
mitigation  measures  required  during  construction  and  to  be  implemented  by  the  contractors  and 
suppliers as part of their contractual obligations. Post-construction environmental mitigation will be 
the  responsibility  of  the  agencies  responsible  for  the  operations  and  maintenance  of  the 
infrastructure provided under the project—the irrigation and drainage management companies and 
the irrigation management companies. 
 
F. 

Public Consultation and Disclosure 

13. 
The  public  consultation  and  participation  process  was  comprised  of  reconnaissance 
surveys, socioeconomic surveys, and participatory meetings. Public consultations for both the new 

 

 54 

Appendix 11 

WRU campus and BHH subprojects were conducted during the design of the project. Further public 
consultations will be held during detailed design, construction, and operation. 
 

1. 

WRU Campus 

14. 
The first public consultation meeting was held in Chuong My District People's Committee on 
17 June 2009 with 121 participants. The purpose was to introduce the environmental assessment 
procedures and follow-up activities. Comments were collected from participants.  
 

2. 

Bac Hung Hai  

15. 
Eight public consultation meetings in the various BHH subproject locations were conducted 
from  14  to  21  December  2009.  A  total  of  256  participants  attended  the  meetings.  The  purposes 
were  to  collect  information;  present  subprojects  details,  including  designs  and  locations  as 
presented in the draft IEE; and learn about social and environmental issues and concerns. 
 
G. 

Findings and Recommendations 

1. 

WRU Campus  

16. 
The realization of the WRU campus will have a strong positive impact on higher education 
in  Viet  Nam.  Screening  of  environmental  impacts  also  revealed  adverse  effects  from  the  project, 
but  all  appeared  to  be  small  or  moderate  and  many  are  temporary.  No  significant  adverse 
environmental  impacts  are  expected  from  the  construction  of  the  new  WRU  campus.  The  main 
environmental  impacts  are  resettlement  during  construction; the  generation  of  solid  waste;  noise, 
air, and water pollution; temporary flooding and traffic congestion during construction; air pollution; 
risk  of  accidents;  disposal  of  waste;  and  volumes  of  wastewater  during  operation.  Mitigation 
measures have been formulated that can diminish adverse impacts. 
 

2. 

Bac Hung Hai  

17. 
The  realization  of  the  BHH  subprojects  will  have  a  strong  positive  impact  on  the  BHH 
system  by  increasing  the  water  supply  for  irrigation,  expanding  the  drained  area,  additional 
pumping  capacity,  improved  enforcement  of  regulations,  improved  coordination  and  system 
management, and improved cost recovery. Intensified flushing will have some positive effect on the 
quality  of  surface  waters  in  the  BHH  system.  However,  substantiating  the  true  effect  will  require 
intensive  water  quality  monitoring  supported  by  mathematical  modeling.  Screening  of  potential 
environmental  impacts  revealed  adverse  effects  from  the  proposed  subprojects.  However,  all 
adverse  impacts  appeared  to  be  small  or  moderate,  and  many  are  temporary.  Adverse  impact  is 
expected  from  the  pump  stations’  discharging  polluted  drainage  water  into  the  rivers  around  the 
BHH  system,  which  needs  comprehensive  mitigation  measures  by  the  government.  Other  than 
that,  no  severe  environmental  impacts  are  expected,  only  temporary  ones  mainly  during 
construction,  which  can  be  mitigated  through  sound  engineering  practices  and  measures  to  be 
detailed in the EMPs.  
 
H. 

Conclusions 

18. 
The proposed subprojects for the BHH system and the new WRU campus pose only slight 
and moderate adverse environmental impacts. They can be resolved by proper design, mitigations 
measures,  and  correct  operations  and  maintenance.  For  these  reasons  the  IEE  for  the  BHH 
subprojects and the WRU campus component is sufficient, according to Asian Development Bank's 
environmental guidelines and regulations. A more detailed EMP will be updated for WRU and the 
BHH  system  during  project  detailed  design  to  control  and  mitigate  small  and  moderate  adverse 
environmental impacts.

SUMMARY ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 

Introduction 

Beneficiaries and Overall Project Benefits 

 
A. 
 
1. 
The project is designed to support the Government of Viet Nam in its effort to promote the 
sustainability  of  the  national  water  resources  as  enshrined  in  the  National  Water  Resources 
Strategy,  where  the  main  objectives  for  the  water  sector  in  the  next  15  years  are  defined  as  the 
protection,  efficient  exploitation,  and  sustainable  development  of  water  resources  on  the  basis  of 
integrated  and  unified  water  resources  management.  The  project  will  contribute  to  accelerated 
growth  in  terms  of  income  and  improved  food  security  for  rural  households  through  improved 
agricultural  productivity  and  increased  crop  diversification.  The  project  will  result  in  (i)  improved 
education  for  water  sector  professionals  and  technicians,  stronger  water  sector  research  and 
development  programs,  and  upgraded  educational  facilities  with  equipment  for  Water  Resource 
University  (WRU);  (ii)  strengthened  institutional  capacity  of  water-related  service  providers  in  the 
Bac Hung Hai (BHH) irrigation and drainage system; and (iii) enhanced infrastructure in the BHH 
system. 
 
B. 
 
2. 
The BHH component of the project will cover four provinces in the Red River Delta region 
that share the system: Bac Ninh, Ha Noi City, Hai Duong, and Hung Yen. It is expected to benefit 
540,000  households,  or  2.7  million  people,  through  system  investments,  training,  and  capacity 
building. Most households in the project provinces are involved in agricultural production, ranging 
from  60%  to  98%  across  project  districts,  and  are  smallholders  with  less  than  0.2  hectares  of 
usable agricultural land. 
 
3. 
Capacity building is a key element for developing and implementing strategies and policies 
in water resources management in general and in relation to agriculture sector development. The 
project investment in the WRU will help increase the number of bachelor of science graduates by 
135% and of master of science graduates by 340% by 2020 through newly constructed educational 
facilities  for  13,400  students,  to  be  completed  in  2012.  The  classrooms  will  have  a  capacity  of 
9,930  students  and  the  lecture  halls  of  4,500  students.  This  assistance  together  with  curriculum 
reforms  will  help  the  government  to  ensure  that  the  management  of  irrigation  and  drainage 
complies  with  the  needs  of  other  fields  of  water  management,  such  as  hydropower,  the 
development of industry, urbanization, diversification of agriculture, forestry, fishery, etc. Educated 
staff  are  expected  to  make  the  required  adjustments  and  introduce  innovations  to  meet  the 
increasing demands of industrialization and modernization in the years to come. 
 
4. 

The project is expected to yield major benefits: 

(i) 

Incremental  benefits  from  higher  yields  and  productivity  of  crops  and  other  agro-
products will come from upgraded hydraulic structures and equipment for controlling 
the  timing  and  allocation  of  irrigation  water  and  improving  agricultural  and  non-
agricultural drainage conditions. 

(ii) 

Saved  irrigation  water  will  be  available  for  allocation  to  other  community  livelihood 
needs. 

(iii) 

Greater protection of people and their assets from flooding. 

(iv) 

Improved  knowledge  through  capacity  building  and  practical  training  in  more 
efficient institutional arrangements will enhance water user participation in irrigation 
and drainage system management. 

 

 56 

Appendix 12 

(v) 

The project will make significant contributions to reducing rural poverty in the project 
provinces. This will help ease social pressures to migrate to urban centers like Ha 
Noi  and  Hai  Phong  and  contribute  to  balanced  development  in  Viet  Nam  in  the 
medium term. 

 
C. 
 

Economic Analyses of the Project 

1. 

Methodology and Assumptions 

 
The  economic  analyses  of  project  investments  in  the  BHH  irrigation  and  drainage  system 
5. 
were prepared in line with Asian Development Bank guidelines, handbooks, and technical notes.1 
The project has an implementation period of 6 years from 2010 to 2016, and the economic life of 
the project interventions is assumed to be 20 years. For the current analysis, the exchange rate of 
D18,300 = $1 has been used.2 A discount rate of 12% was used to estimate the net present value 
and serves as a cut-off point for the economic internal rate of return (EIRR).  
 
6. 
The economic analysis determined incremental benefits attributable to project interventions. 
Although a number of benefit streams are observed, the analysis includes only readily quantifiable 
benefits  attributable  to  project  interventions.  Financial  revenue  and  costs  were  estimated  using 
constant  October  2009  prices.  Financial  farm-gate  prices  were  based  on  findings  and  collated 
information  collected  during  the  socioeconomic  surveys  by  the  project  preparatory  technical 
assistance  consultant  team  and  the  Asian  Development  Bank  fact-finding  mission  in  November 
2009,  together  with  information  made  available  by  the  Ministry  of  Agriculture  and  Rural 
Development  (MARD)  and  various  national  production  associations.  The  analyses  use  a  world 
price  numeraire  where  economic  prices  for  traded  crop  inputs  and  outputs  have  been  based  on 
World  Bank  commodity  price  projections.  Labor  costs  have  been  shadow-priced  at  0.85  of  the 
wage  rates,  while  other  inputs  have  been  adjusted  by  the  standard  conversion  factor  of  0.90  as 
applicable  to  Viet  Nam.  The  economic  viability  of  the  project  is  evaluated  against  standard 
benchmarks: EIRR >12%, benefit–cost ratio >1, and economic net present value >0. 
 
7. 
The  economic  analyses  are  presented  in  the  following  section.  Detailed  assumptions, 
financial and economic production budgets, derived economic prices, project capital and recurrent 
costs  profiles,  and  benefit–cost  and  sensitivity  analyses  are  in  Supplementary  Appendix  N  and 
associated Excel models. 
 

2. 

Project Investment Profile 

 
The Bac Hung Hai irrigation and drainage system is located southeast of Ha Noi. The area 
8. 
of the system, including 22,887 hectares outside the dikes, is 215,956 hectares, of which 126,980 
hectares (66% of the area inside the dikes) is used for agriculture. The population of the area is 2.7 
million people, 81% of whom are involved in agricultural production. In recent years, the Integrated 
Water  Resource  Program  carried  out  an  extensive  water  resources  study  for  the  BHH  area  and 
prepared proposals for rehabilitating and developing infrastructure.  
 
9. 
The main purpose of the investments is to replace a number of key pumping stations that 
have  outlived  their  technical  life  and  renovate  a  number  of  pumping  stations  by  fitting  them  with 
new  pumps,  as  the  present  ones  are  no  longer  in  service.  In  addition, new  pumping  stations  are 
added to expand the irrigation and drainage system to its original design extent and adapt the BHH

3. 

Project Benefits 

a. 

Quantified Benefits  

 
The main purpose of the BHH project interventions is to retain the productive capacity of the 
10. 
land by maintaining and improving irrigation and drainage. The interventions are not geared toward 
introducing new farming practices. Most quantified project benefits are derived from increased yield 
of crops and aquaculture attributable to improved irrigation water availability in the BHH system.  
 
11. 
Data  on  the  cultivated  area,  yield,  and  production  of  crops  and  aquaculture  in  2008  were 
collected at the district level and converted into BHH sub-area cropping patterns and yields, using 
area-based conversion rates. Agricultural land-use areas for 2015 and 2020 were estimated on the 
basis of expected reduction of agricultural land that will shift to other land uses such as industrial, 
urban, and residential zone development. The "with project" cropping patterns and intensities have 
been identified at the sub-area level on the basis of the agricultural development orientation of the 
project provinces for 2015 and 2020. The increases of yields are forecasted on the basis of trends 
during 2001–2008 in the Red River Delta and on potential new variety applications and increased 
cropping intensities enabled by better and more timely water supply. For the "without project" case 
it  has  been  assumed  that  agricultural  production  and  cultivated  areas  will  continue  developing 
similarly  as  in  the  "with  project"  case.  However,  due  to  unreliable  irrigation  supply  and  expected 
inundation, crop yields have been forecasted lower than in the “with project” case. The 2008, 2015, 
and 2020 "with project" and "without project" cropping patterns and production are calculated along 
with the potential net incremental benefits (both financial and economic) for each sub-area and for 
the entire BHH system. Net incremental benefits from increased yield of crops and aquaculture are 
summarized in Table A12.2.

13. 
In  terms  of  benefits  from  increased  yield  of  crops  and  aquaculture,  critical  conditions 
required  to  bring  about  the  predicted  agricultural  productivity  increases  other  than  water  (the 
availability of inputs, knowledge to use improved seeds and fertilizers, and willingness of farmers to 
adopt and invest in new technology) are largely in place. The BHH project area is one of the best-
developed  agricultural  areas  of  Viet  Nam  and  a  key  driver  lifting  Viet  Nam  from  being  a  rice 
importer to being a rice exporter since the economic open-door policy was adopted in 1986. The 
project areas are located close to Ha Noi and the port city of Hai Phong and include the urbanized 
Ha  Noi  City  districts  of  Long  Bien  and  Gia  Lam  and  the  provincial  capitals  of  Hung  Yen  and  Hai 
Duong provinces. These constitute large markets for agricultural products. At the commune level, 
departments of agriculture and rural development (DARDs) provide extension services. Credit for 
agricultural inputs is available from the Vietnam Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development, which 
has  a  branch  office  in  each  BHH  district  and  intercommune  branches  in  every  three  communes. 
More  importantly,  access  to  loan  financing  has  been  made  easier  by  the  Vietnam  Bank  for 
Agriculture and Rural Development requiring no collateral for loans smaller than D10 million ($550). 

 

 Appendix 12      59 

This is the size of loan often taken by smallholder farmers. Agricultural marketing information from 
DARDs  is  available  to  producers  via  various  channels  including  the  Agroviet  website.3  MARD  is 
testing  a  system  to  provide  marketing  information  through  mobile  phones,  now  widely  used  by 
smallholder  farmers  in  the  project  area.  For  input  supply  and  marketing,  the  BHH  area  is  well 
connected by road with Highway No. 5 (Ha Noi–Hai Phong) and new bridges over the Red River at 
Vinh Tuy and Thanh Tri already in place and two more under construction at Nhat Tan and Tu Lien. 
A  new  deep  seaport  for  the  north  of  Viet  Nam  is  under  construction  in  Cai  Lan  in  Quang  Ninh 
Province, which will be well connected to the BHH area via National Road No. 18 from Bac Ninh to 
Cai Lan. Railway and inland water transport are available in the BHH area but of minor importance 
to agriculture.

Besides quantifiable benefits, there is a variety of benefits that cannot be readily quantified.

15. 
Second,  improved  irrigation  normally  has  both  direct  benefits  accruing  to  the  farming 
community  and  indirect  benefits  accruing  to  the  wider  local  economy.  The  indirect  benefits  of 
improved  irrigation  include  backward  linkage  effects  because  of  additional  inputs  (labor  and 
material inputs) used in the irrigated agriculture due to improved crop productivity made possible by 
better access to irrigation. Indirect effects of irrigation are due to income and employment effects in 
the  agro-industry  sector  and  non-farm  sectors  of  the  rural  economy.  The  indirect  benefits  of 
irrigation,  such  as  increases  in  direct  agriculture  production  as  well  as  allied  agriculture  sector 
activities,  spread  to  the  region  as  a  whole  and  increase  other  rural  agro-services  and  marketing 
activities  in  the  economy.  Therefore,  the  indirect  benefits  of  irrigation  also  play  a  larger  role  for 
poverty alleviation and maintaining food security than does the direct benefit in term of increased 
crop  productivity.  Although  It  is  not  easy  to  quantify  these  benefits  precisely,  in  developing 
economies  such  as  Viet  Nam  where  agriculture  production  is  better  organized  than  elsewhere  in 
the developing world, the irrigation multiplication factors have been observed to be in the range of 
1.5–2.0 times direct benefits. 
 
Third, the project will assist the government in capacity building at the national, provincial, 
16. 
and  district  levels.  Though  difficult  to  quantify,  benefits  derived  from  capacity  building  for  MARD,

WRU,  DARDs,  and  entities  operating  the  BHH  system  will  ensure  improved  water  resource 
management in the country in the medium and long term. 
 

4. 

Summary Economic Indicators 

 
The EIRR was calculated for the project to determine its economic viability and serve as the 
17. 
monitoring  benchmark  for  project  implementation.  The  results  of  the  economic  analysis  are 
summarized in Table A12.5. The base-case EIRR was estimated at 22.4%, economic net present 
value at $69.5 million, and benefit–cost ratio at 1.64. These indicators suggest that the project is 
economically  viable,  with  a  base-case  EIRR  well  above  the  12%  economic  opportunity  cost  of 
capital for the quantified benefits. In addition, there are irrigation multiplication impacts, and other 
social,  environmental,  and  capacity-building  benefits  that  have  not  been  quantified  because  of 
measuring  difficulties  and  lack  of  data.  Except  for  flood  protection,  benefits  were  estimated;  they 
were  not  included  in  the  benefit–cost  analysis  as  annual  frequencies  and  magnitude  were 
uncertain. Therefore, the current analysis presents a conservative estimate of the project benefits.

18. 
Sensitivity  tests  were  undertaken  to  test  the  robustness  of  the  analyses  and  examine  the 
consequences of changes in variables, including capital costs, operations and maintenance of civil 
infrastructure,  system  dredging  costs,  benefits,  pumping  costs,  and  an  earlier  pump  replacement 
schedule. The tests were undertaken with the following variables: (i) increase of 10% in the capital 
cost, (ii) increase of 10% in civil infrastructure operations and maintenance costs, (iii) increase of 
10%  in  system  dredging  costs,  (iv)  combined  ii  and  iii,  (v)  decrease  of  10%  in  benefits,  (vi) 
combined iv and v, (vii) decrease of 20% in benefits, (viii) increase of 10% in pumping costs, (ix) 1-
year delay in benefits, and (x) pumps replaced after 15 years instead of 20 years.4 The sensitivity 
analysis results for the project are outlined in Table A12.5. The sensitivity tests indicate that these 
subprojects are slightly sensitive to the adverse impacts of various factors including the assumed 
benefit  reduction  of  20%  due  to  low  water  levels  during  the  dry  season.  However,  the  analysis

 D.  

Fiscal Impact Analysis 

Appendix 12      61 

19. 
The  fiscal  impact  of  the  project  is  important  as  it  helps  assess  sustainability.  In  practice, 
rural infrastructure rehabilitation projects often support capital costs. However, the sustainability of 
recurrent  costs  is  an  issue  of  central  importance  in  the  economic  analysis.  The  impact  on  the 
overall  budget  after  project  completion  often  determines  whether  the  project  outcome  will  be 
sustained in the long run. Key issues to be addressed include what impacts the investment in the 
project  has  on  fiscal  indicators  such  as  annual  state  budget  allocation,  capital  replacement,  and 
recurrent expenditure requirements during and after project implementation.  

20. 
Detailed  fiscal  analyses  indicate  that  the  proposed  capital  cost  is  affordable  to  all  project 
provinces.  Table  A12.6  presents  recurrent  cost  outlays  estimated  for  BHH  system  rehabilitation. 
The  estimated  costs  during  project  implementation  are  committed  by  the  central  government. 
When  project  implementation  comes  to  an  end,  annual  costs  to  be  borne  by  public  utilities  are 
estimated  at  $4.9  million,  while  annual  cost  recovery  from  irrigation  service  fees  is  nil  due  to  the 
irrigation  service  fee  waiver  policy.  However,  the  provincial  peoples'  committees  in  the  project 
provinces will be able to afford an outlay of up to $1.5 million per year to maintain the subprojects 
in  their  jurisdictions,  leaving  an  annual  deficit  of  $3.4  million  to  be  allocated  by  the  central 
government.  This  level  of  government  subsidy  is  considered  affordable  in  the  context  of 
development in Viet Nam. However, it is important that the project operating entities incorporate the 
recurrent cost financing schedule into their annual provincial submissions to the National Assembly 
during the current year to ensure adequate funds are made available for the following year.

21. 
The  financial  management  assessment  of  the  WRU  concluded  that  it  has  extensive 
experience  in  managing  official  development  assistance  funds  and  will  have  adequate  revenue 
from  increased  student  fees  and  government  subsidy  to  sustain  operations.  With  the  project  it  is 
projected  that  future  revenue  from  tuition  fees  will  grow  at  a  annual  rate  of  15%,  which  is 
significantly higher than in the past due to (i) a higher level of tuition fees applied since 2009, (ii) a 
larger  number  of  students,  and  (iii)  a  fewer  number  of  students  who  qualify  for  fee  reduction  or 
exemption. It is also projected that annual government financial support for WRU will nearly double 
by 2016. At the same time the growth of expenditure is expected to decline from an annual rate of 
16% during 2004-2008 to 13% by 2016 (Supplementary Appendix O).
